CONTENT_NAME: Inclusion
SUMMARY_TEXT: This is a story about inclusion, and how a small effort to include someone who is different can make a huge difference.
TEXT:
By Alain Labreque

My Granddaughter Myka is a beautiful, intelligent, 8-year-old child, and she is disabled. She has been in physical, occupational, and speech therapies since she was 7 months old. After years of tests, MRI’s, and meetings with developmental and neurological specialists, she and her mother (my daughter in law) were diagnosed with a genetic abnormality. She has a deleted gene. It is a very rare condition. In some cases, the person would never know that they have this condition. In Myka, the symptoms are more obvious. 

The deleted gene is most impactful on the brain. It impacts motor functions in her brain which then relates to basically everything she does, both gross or fine motor. This impacts walking, running, jumping, but also reading, writing, talking. In addition, Myka has low muscle tone which also impacts all her motor functions.

Myka did not crawl as baby until she was 15 months old. She worked with a physical therapist for one and a half years to accomplish what most babies do in 5 months. From there, Myka was able to walk at 2 years old. She is now able to walk and run, but she is working on the ability to jump or hop. The two combined muscle issues cause Myka to easily lose her balance and she trips and falls more than a typical child.

The deleted gene also effects the neuropathways. Myka is neurodivergent, she gets overwhelmed in loud noisy spaces, she retreats when surrounded by crowds, she has difficulty focusing on tasks, and she has difficulty regulating her behavior when she is tired or overwhelmed.

The most obvious of Myka’s symptoms is her speech. Myka is non-verbal. She can sign a few words, but her neuropathways do not always find the right word. The muscles that we use to speak have not been fully trained for her to easily voice her words. She can say a few words that are perfectly clear but for the most part she can’t speak.

Myka is intelligent, she has learned to communicate by a combination of saying the few words she can say, sign language, and pointing at what she needs. She has taken me by the hand to lead me to a picture of juice to show me what she wants. Myka is extraordinary and does not often get frustrated by her situation. Life is more difficult for her in all aspects, and she accepts that and tries her best to overcome her obstacles. Everything a neurotypical child does takes Myka 10X the effort. Neurotypical people do not consider that aspect in working with those who are differently abled.

I am describing Myka’s condition because it is complicated and not fully defined by modern medicine. When one looks at Myka one would see a very happy child. She has enormous blue eyes and light brown curly hair. She is usually smiling. Her disability is not visually apparent. 

Myka’s classmates accept Myka for who she is. They do not judge her and they usually help her throughout the day. Unfortunately, the sad part of Myka’s story is how adults dismiss her when they learn she has a disability. I have witnessed people calling on Myka to participate in an activity, find out she is non-verbal and instantly dismiss her.

Myka has dealt with adults who talk about her while she is standing next to them hearing everything they say. Adults seem to think that because she can’t talk then she also can’t hear their unkind comments. Her differences have been pointed out to her classmates as if she should be ostracized. “Oh look she doesn’t even say Hi.” I cannot begin to describe the heartbreak and fury I feel when these things happen. She has a slightly crestfallen look on her face as she tries her best and more to keep up but knows she is somehow different.

One day at the end of the school year, my daughter got a notice that Myka’s class was putting on a show during their Friday assembly. Myka was expected to participate in the show. We knew that Myka might have an issue with the crowds, and we didn’t know if she would be able to participate in the event.  Earlier in the year, she went on a field trip with her class to see a show. She ended up sitting outside the show because she was getting overwhelmed. We worried about her participating in this school event.

We all walked Myka to school to support her during the performance. Her 4-year-old brother was very excited to see Myka. We made our way to the assembly and anxiously waited for the show to start. The class came in and they were all carrying signs with various animals on them. Myka was positioned surrounded by her classmates and her Special Education teacher (known as Ms Q) was right behind her. She was happily looking around at the crowds and was very relaxed. Seeing that Myka was happy we all relaxed to enjoy the show.

The show was children singing and waving their animal signs. At certain points in the show, sets of children would run up on stage to play xylophones to accompany the singing. Myka was happily singing and standing in her spot. She was included in the group. The show was long, the children were singing and playing the xylophone, and the music teacher was running from one set of children to the other. It was chaotic, and Myka was enjoying it. She did not falter, and she did not get overwhelmed.

Towards the end of the show, we noticed that Myka was not in her spot. I worried that she got upset and needed to be removed. Suddenly, we saw Myka walk on the stage with Ms Q. She sat down to play the xylophone, just like her classmates. She had a huge smile on her face and was clearly enjoying every minute. I cried at seeing her be able to participate as much as her classmates.

At the end of the show, we stayed behind to say hello to Myka and tell her we are so proud of her. She hugged us all and was especially happy to see that her baby brother got to see her. Myka was clearly very proud of herself and so happy to fully participate, she was glowing.

Ms. Q was with Myka the whole time. Ms. Q and said she really wanted Myka have the full experience. Ms. Q had arranged special rehearsal sessions for Myka to practice going on stage. She and the children worked with Myka so she understood what was expected and how it felt to be on stage. They took the extra step to include her and worked with her until she was comfortable going in front of a group of people. 

It’s difficult to pin down how this inclusion influences someone. Myka has gained confidence this year and I believe the extra effort to include her is partly why. Myka is trying more and more to say words, and her vocabulary is growing. She went to a summer camp daycare and participated in a song and dance show. One of the daycare teachers taught her some basic sign language and she is using that to communicate. She was included in a way that didn’t emphasize her differences but simply accepted her for who she is. That inclusion increased her confidence to keep trying new things.

In conclusion, I ask that you think to yourself. Have I taken any extra steps to include anyone who is outside of my circle including different abilities, different cultures, or any other difference? Have I unceremoniously dismissed someone who may need additional support to perform a task? Have I unconsciously talked about someone (usually a child) believing that they don’t understand or hear me? We are all beautifully different humans, and we all deserve to be treated with respect and given opportunities to be included. I have witnessed the positive effects and I vow to follow the example shown to me. Please join me.

CONTENT_NAME: Professional Development Opportunities through FranklinCovey All Access Pass
TEXT:
By Elyse Rosenberg

As you work with your managers and supervisors on People and Service objectives for the new Fiscal Year, we wanted to remind you about the great resources in the FranklinCovey All Access Pass. BTS is continuing its investment in providing employees with the All Access Pass because of its valuable content in connection to the City’s Core Values and our commitment, in partnership with the Labor Management Committee, to building a culture of High Trust.

This pass provides access to training solutions including live, webinar and self-paced options. You can access resources like:

  • OnDemand Impact Journeys: Multi-week self-paced learning experiences built around core FranklinCovey content with activities and reminder sent to you via email.  Here are a few examples:
    • Inspire a Culture of Trust
    • Inclusive Leadership: Practical Ways to Cultivate Inclusion & Build a Better Team
    • Change: How to Turn Uncertainty Into Opportunity
  • OnDemand Microcourses and Microlearning Library: Skill-specific courses that take minutes to complete and easy-to-browse tips for everyday reference. Here are a few examples:
    • Collaborating with multiple stakeholders
    • 4 surprising phrases to help you get better results in negotiations
    • Self-doubt holding you back? 4 strategies to overcome it

You might use the All Access Pass to find content that helps further your professional development plan around communication or leadership, develops skills in confronting bias, or contributes to a trust huddle.

Many BTS employees already have access! BTS has invested in 200 All Access Pass licenses and, in order get the best value this investment, we require a commitment to log in and use the All Access Pass at least 4 times over the next year.

If you’re a City employee and you don’t currently have a license but would like to request access, please reach out to BTS’s All Access Pass Administrators Mike Lamb, Ashish Gupta, or Edith Brown.

CONTENT_NAME: Communication and Autism (Part three of three)
TEXT:
By Ian Arnold


Part Three of Three

What can you do to help Autists participate?

My suggestions here will largely focus on the formal settings, and a lot of the adjustments that came with the response to the pandemic have addressed these and opened different ways to work.  The overall theme of this section will boil down to one thing – be flexible in how you allow others to show up.

Virtual meetings often make the pace of meetings easier to process. There is often a slight delay in someone else adding to a conversation, either due to coming off mute or waiting to be acknowledged by the person running the meeting. Virtual meetings allow for an individual to have a bit more control of their environment, like using a focus room as a physical space to attend the meeting. It also makes contributing easier as people can type in responses or raise hands to not interrupt.

Virtual meetings also have downsides. In team settings where multiple people are on a virtual meeting while sitting next to each other, it can cause a lot of audio processing issues as you can end up with three audio steams of one person talking (e.g., person talking in the room, their audio on Teams, and their audio coming through someone else’s mic who are not on mute). In these settings, consider moving the team to a conference room with the option to attend virtually if someone needs it.

I have also seen a lot of people discuss pushing for people to turn on cameras to make sure they engage with the discussion more. And while this can be true for allistic extroverts, it can have the opposite impact for Autists. Having a camera on can distract us from the meeting as we suddenly have an increased pressure to mask and appear as if we are focused instead of doing what allows us to actually focus. This can lead to lower contribution rate as we are more aware of the camera than the meeting. But even asking for people to turn on cameras , if comfortable, can cause Autists to turn on cameras when they aren’t comfortable in an attempt to mask as it appears expected.

Regardless of what type of meeting you are in create space for contribution. From my experience, people in BTS are pretty good about this already – but I still want to bring this up. It is always good to check if anyone else wants to add something to a topic before moving on from it, and actually give a pause for them to chime in. I have worked with multiple companies that do more of a “and if no one has anything else to say moving on to…” and continue right into the next topic, forcing someone to interrupt if they want to speak. This is something that many Autists are not comfortable doing because of rules they were taught earlier in life. Teams makes this a bit easier with the ability to raise a hand, or type in the chat. I often raise a hand even in person because it is just easier even if it feels a bit odd.

As for the informal, I wish I had more tips on this as this is something I continue to work on myself and hear many other Autists struggle with. A big part of this is not felling like we can be ourselves and the need to mask to be present in these settings. Many Autists report they find friendship and social interactions to just be easier with other neurodivergent people. However, I can say if you want to include Autists in something, you need to explicitly invite them. Many Autists joke that we are like vampires, we can’t come in unless invited. Saying things like, “A bunch of us are going to go grab lunch from the food carts.” may be received as just the sharing of information instead of the intended invitation. So, making sure to add the explicit invitation, “Would you like to join us?” afterward will clarify that you are inviting them.

I have heard several Autists discuss activity-based events being easier to attend, and this is certainly true for myself. It is much easier to go to something knowing that there is a specific thing I am there to do, and I can make an informed decision if it is something I want to go to. Just having a social get together with a group is extremely vague, often has no specific end time, and is often based solely around conversation. For me this is one of the reasons I love board games and was very active with the Oregon Bartenders’ Guild. Both provide me chances to socialize with a specific interest as the focal point if it is needed and I can gauge how long I am going to be there before going.  

I don’t have a great way to close this out other than to say thank you. Thank you for taking the time to read this. Thank you for contributing to our organization being one that is open and accepting of people with different backgrounds, experience, and ability. If you want to learn more some really good resources exist in social media and advocacy networks. If on Instagram lookup @nourdivergent_lou for some quick insight from an Autist and educator on many specific topics and experiences. If you want to read what is happening in the community and changes the community are pushing for check out the Autistic Self Advocacy Network’s website.

CONTENT_NAME: Communication and Autism (Part two of three)
TEXT:
By Ian Arnold


Part Two of Three

See disclaimer in Part 1.

Communication in one-on-one settings

Growing up we are taught to sit still and make eye contact to show we are listening and give a firm handshake when meeting someone. For Autists these things can be harmful. Autists often don’t pick up on body language and looking someone in the eye can be physically uncomfortable for them. Some are very sensitive of personal space and having a hand thrust out for a handshake can feel like an attack.

Being allowed to position ourselves how we need in a conversation can allow us to give attention to the person speaking and put us at ease. This can be as minor as looking at the ground, or as major as turning away from the speaker. Keep in mind that someone does not need to be looking at you to hear you. Look for other ways of confirming you are being heard and understood.

Communication breakdowns

I can’t tell you how often I walk away from a conversation wondering if I was having the same conversation as the person I was talking to. I often find that I’ll say something and later find out a person took a whole different meaning from it than what was said. Autists often report communicating in literal terms. Something I find is often useful in explaining this experience is connotation versus denotation.

Connotation is the inferred meaning often relying on context or societal norms and can often have nothing to do with the dictionary definition of the meaning.

Denotation is the dictionary definition of something. It has a specific, literal meaning. Now, most Autists don’t go and read through a dictionary, but I know for myself when I come across a word I don’t know, the first thing I do is look it up. 

Personally, this leads to a lot of confusion. I might be having a conversation, speaking in denotation and understanding in denotation, but the person I am talking to has a completely different understanding of things because they are using all the connotations of their lived experience. I will say I greatly appreciate Speed of Trust’s point of Talk Straight for this very reason and struggle a lot with that kind of bloated corporate speak where everything is masked in vague aggrandized terms. This all extends to things like sarcasm, colloquialisms, and jokes.

Sarcasm

Very interesting thing within Autists. I am, and know several others, that are often very sarcastic, and yet tend to be pretty bad at picking up on other’s sarcasm. This has a lot to do with learning sarcasm as part of scripting, but not understanding body language and tone enough to pick up on it from others. This can become even worse in forms of written communication where there are no context clues for me to try and piece together.

Colloquialisms

Many phrases that are used regularly make absolutely no sense or are straight horrifying when read through the lens of denotation. “It’s raining cats and dogs,” what a horrifying statement. Now for myself I have learned to process this phrase for its connotation of “its heavily raining outside,” but my mind has to hear the phrase, process that there are not literal cats and dogs falling from the sky (and suppress the emotional response to how awful of an event this would be), and finally recall the meaning of this phrase. While all of that happens in a matter of a second, doing this throughout a day can cause mental fatigue. Many Autists will learn, and even use, these phrases as part of masking and scripting. But they will still have internal thoughts of how ridiculous the phrases are or must exert extra energy to redirect their speech to use them.

Jokes

Some Autists struggle to understand jokes, or our audio processing (or extra time to process connotation) leads us to get the joke much later. I often find myself saying something funny and not even processing that it is a joke in the context of a conversation until people laugh, I repeat what I said in my head, and piece together why that was funny after something else that had already been said. I have found when in groups of Allistics I will even need to ask what the joke was, in doing this have found I often enjoy jokes that can be explained around their word play or being about going against an expectation. On the other hand, I have found many people can get angry or uncomfortable being asked to explain a joke – as it shows the joke was in bad taste. Part of Autists masking can often be laughing along at jokes that are not understood or make them uncomfortable. None of this is to say Autists do not have good senses of humor, I especially love puns and word play and Hannah Gadsby (another Autist) is one of my favorite comedians.  Scripting also makes it fairly easy for Autists to be funny as they learn comedic timing and how to respond to phrases or situations from TV shows and movies.

Communication in group settings

Communication in group settings can be extremely difficult for Autists. Trying to keep up with a conversation between multiple people while dealing with audio processing issues is enough of a challenge, but it also takes quite a good deal of energy and focus to be able to participate in those settings.  Autists are often dealing with sensory overload, audio processing difficulties, translating connotations to denotations, trying to time when they can speak while adhering to societal things like not interrupting or speaking over someone else, and often masking behaviors of their own to make everyone in the conversation more comfortable.

Sensory overload presents in different ways for Autists. It could be something as minor as getting a new shirt that is a slightly different material than what they are used to, and it is causing a sensation as drastic as feeling like something is scraping over their skin. Sensory overload could also include lights in the room are too bright, or the sound of the projector in a room is being picked up at an equal level as the person speaking, or the scent of a team members perfume/cologne can be smelled from across the room (even though no one else notices it). I find this especially difficult in settings with multiple conversations. I’ve noticed I can hear conversations in a group to the side more clearly than the person I am speaking one-on-one with. Another big one for me is ticking clocks. If there is an analog clock in a room, I can hear it like it is right next to my ear - making it almost impossible for me to focus on other things.

All of these sensory inputs can make it hard to focus. Even when able to focus, attempting to process audio between everyone in a group conversation can take a while. By the time I process what is said, think about it, and have an opinion or response, I appear slow to respond to things. Add in the effort on my part to adhere to social etiquette and not interrupt or talk over someone, I will often miss a chance to speak. In a work setting, this often has me drafting an email to send to the relevant party after a meeting is over. In a less formal setting like a team lunch I am often left to not engage, or risk saying something on a topic that people moved on from several minutes ago. I will often find myself seeking one-on-one conversation in these environments for this reason and look for physical spots to isolate myself from the majority of the group conversations – corners of rooms or corners of tables are good for this.

As an aside, as part of my ASD I really like structure. Having rules and frameworks with reasons behind them allow me to know expectations of behavior and know that I am behaving correctly. One of the frameworks I use in communication is called the four gates, this comes out of a Sufi teaching. Before I speak, I try to take what I am saying through four questions. These are:

  1. Is what I have to say true?
  2. Does this need to be said/does this need to be said by me?
  3. Is now the appropriate time to say this?
  4. Is what I am saying kind?

These rules help me reframe a lot of what I say, but also cause a further delay in conversation and make every effort to communicate expend more mental energy.

Many Autists operate off the rules they have been taught growing up. These can include things that aren’t very supportive of getting involved in a conversation and can take a lot of work for Autists to reframe their rules. These can influence behaviors like remaining quite in group conversations or speaking bluntly and coming off as rude. This can also leave us in a state of confusion as we interact with people that don’t follow the rules we have been taught. Some examples are:

  • Treat others the way you want to be treated
  • Honesty is the best policy
  • Wait for your turn to speak/ don’t interrupt others
  • Don’t speak unless spoken to

Many Autists find it easier to communicate with other Autists because the others involved are using similar rules. They are able to speak bluntly without the other person taking offense, able to establish trust much quicker as both parties speak honestly, and are often more comfortable in the silence after conversation has ended.

CONTENT_NAME: Communication and Autism (Part one of three)
TEXT:
by Ian Arnold

Part One of Three

An Introduction

Disclaimer: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) has a wide range of levels and areas of impact on how a person relates to the world. I will largely be speaking from my own experiences, but I will also try to expand on topics with things I have heard while speaking with others in the community. I will be focusing on this from the perspective of Autists (Autistic people) who are capable of verbal communication, there are many people on the spectrum who are nonverbal and use augmented and alternative communication. It is important to note these demographics exist and are just as relevant, but as I do not have experience with this to speak from, I will not be covering it here.

I have not been officially diagnosed with ASD, as the way it presents for me caused me to excel in a school environment. Many people go undiagnosed, especially women and people of color, as most research on autism has been done on white males with behaviors that were found disruptive to the allistic world. Many people in the Autistic community self-diagnose for this reason and the community acknowledges and respects self-diagnosis. It was not until my late 20’s that I heard from enough Autists to realize several of the things I experience are not neurotypical experiences, and only after several years of reading about Autists’ experiences, did I start to identify as Autistic.

The focus of this blog post will be on communication, specifically in work environments. It is important to keep in mind that there is no one size fits all way of handling communication, and it is important to create space to establish how to best communicate with someone.

What is Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)?

ASD is the medical term used for a wide range of what the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) calls, ‘neurodevelopmental disorders’ that can impact an individual’s functions including: communication, sensory processing, executive function, and more. While it is often framed negatively,  this is largely due to a history of ableism in the medical field and a focus on deficits rather than an understanding of function. The Autistic community continues to try and reframe these things with perspective of Autists, to give a better understanding of how we function in a world that is not designed for us, rather than looking for lack of ability.

Autists see examples of Autists throughout history and as far back as ancient Egypt. Current research suggests ASD is an inherited genetic trait and has existed for a long time. Due to the limited way it was studied it went largely undiagnosed and misrepresented for much of recent history. Current understanding of it has rates of diagnosis increasing drastically making some people point to modern day environmental factors as the cause. This simply is not true; ASD is just becoming easier to diagnose and acceptance of it is growing so we are seeing the actual numbers for the first time.

Many of the terms used in diagnosing people with ASD are outdated, have ableist mind sets behind them, and were established by people with horrible ethical practices. It is important to understand that each person may prefer different language around being Autistic. I will be referring to myself as Autistic throughout this, but keep in mind some may not like being referred to in that way, and it is best to use the language someone prefers. If you want to read about why I choose to identify as Autistic rather than as someone with autism, there is a fantastic article on the use of identity-first language instead of person-first language on the Autistic Self Advocacy Network’s website.

While I will talk about a lot of different behaviors, it is important to note that autism can be very polarizing in how it presents and can even show both extremes in a single person depending on the situation. Eye contact is a good example. In certain situations, a person may not be able to make any eye contact, while that same person in a different situation makes the most intense eye contact. For me – I struggle to make eye contact while thinking or processing information.

Lastly, I want to introduce you to some terms before I dive further into the topic of communication. These are some terms that are used in the Autistic community around specific behaviors we often exhibit and tactics we have for interacting with people in an allistic world. While I may not talk about these directly while discussing communication, it is important to keep them in mind as they are things Autists may do/use when communicating with others. 

Masking

This is any behavior that an Autist does to hide who they are or how they behave normally in order to pass as neurotypical. Some of us are better at it than others and it takes different amounts of energy depending on the person and the situation they are in.

Scripting

Scripting is a common thing among the Autistic community and one of several things used in masking. Just like one would rehearse for a play we learn lines for specific situations. I worked as a bartender for eight years and scripting is what made that possible. I watched how the senior staff initiated conversations, how they responded to requests, how they cut people off, and how they closed people’s tabs out.  I did better in formal bars than dives because I could hide behind that script more. We may partake in scripted conversation even though it bothers us. A common example of this scenario in the Autistic community is asking, “How are you?” Then there is an expectation to say, “Fine thanks, how are you?” We often go through the script instead of sharing how we feel, even if it bothers us to run through these kinds of surface level dialogues as we want to share, or we struggle to understand the point of the question.

Scripting comes from all kinds of sources: people we are close to, coworkers, tv, movies, books, complete strangers at the checkout stand in a grocery store. Some Autists will seem particularly outgoing because they excel at scripting and have learned exaggerated ways of being or doing things from tv and movies. If you have ever seen the HBO series The Rehearsal, scripting is kind of like that. Every conversation I have; I go over what I said, how the person reacted, and if there was a different way I could have said it. All that so I can have a better script for the next time that situation comes up.

Echolalia

This is a particularly interesting one to me and a word I enjoy a lot. Echolalia is the behavior of repeating sounds or phrases. At home I do this aloud, a lot. In public it is often an internal monologue. This is something that has dual function for me, it either brings me joy as I repeat interesting words or phrases, or it is used as a tool to help me process a sound or information. In conversations, I will frequently pair it with a, “Sorry, what was that?” to allow myself time to process internally what they originally said while the person repeats themselves. For other Autists, this may include repeating a word at the end of a sentence, repeating back what was said to them, or just speaking something repeatedly.

Stimming

This is an important one to know as it is often the most observable. This is something many neurodivergent people do to ground themselves, focus, release energy, or stay present. It is often seen as fidgeting and has endless ways of presenting. For me, I often tap my thumb to my fingertips or tap the side of my thumb on my desk or keyboard. For others, it may come as rubbing a shirt, twirling their hair, bouncing their leg, or jerking their body. While this kind of behavior is often seen as disruptive it is tremendously helpful for many of us to stay present in meetings, focus on tasks, and remain comfortable in environments with a lot of sensory input.

Infodumping

Autists often have hyper fixations – which is a particular category or topic they are really interested in that they could talk passionately about for a long time. They are often excited when an opportunity to speak about this comes up and may begin sharing a lot without much room for others to add to the conversation. This is commonly referred to as infodumping. When you see someone go from disengaged in a conversation to dominating a conversation you may have discovered one of their hyper fixations. These topics can and will often change for people over time and can last anywhere from a day to a lifetime. The excitement of these topics will often lead us to break social etiquette we may otherwise try really hard to follow, like jumping into a conversation and talking over someone to share a fact we find really cool. It is often these hyper fixations that leave people with ASD uninterested in small talk as they want to get into the gritty details of things they are excited for, or something someone else is excited about. These can be on any category, but because of the flawed research that has been done there is an assumption these will be on categories like trains (many of the medical diagnostics used will actually ask if someone likes trains). Some people’s hyper fixations will be much more socially acceptable than others, increasing the ease of which they can mask.

SUMMARY_TEXT: The Expedition to the Exhibition of Gender Identity
TEXT:
By Tom Lupton

The idea

When I’m not here at work helping transform our beloved city’s business strategies into working services, I’m a fashion photographer and artist.

I’d like to share with you a memorable event – one where I learned some amazing things about people and about myself.

In February 2020 (yeah, right before the pandemic), Portland Center Stage asked me to do an exhibit to coincide with the punk rock opera Hedwig and the Angry Inch. Decades earlier my theater nerd friends had turned me on to the show with its gut-wrenching passion and outlandish in-your-face fashion escapades, so I jumped at the chance!

After a few fits and starts about the exhibit's theme - drag queen style, disguise, transformation - I realized it needed reality to make it meaningful.

So I whipped open Facebook and posted, “I am doing a new exhibit, and I’m looking for LGBTQ+ people to shoot”. Within moments I had various reactions of “like” and “love” and "pick me". I thought “Ah heck this could turn into a nightmare” and edited the post saying, “this IS NOT a fashion shoot – it might not be pretty or beautiful”. I stepped away for a while wondering if I’d made the right decision, and came back to a flood of volunteers.

“Be you, but be as you as you can be”.

“What should I wear? What should I bring?” they asked. This was the crucial point of the whole process. Do I control it, or do I relinquish control and capture what I see? In a large project like this, it’s usually extremely important to control it for consistency and quality. I remembered how important reality was to this project though, and made a commitment to honor whatever they gave me.

I knew close to nothing about the community I had enlisted. If I had choregraphed the shoot, I would have attempted to “shoot them as I saw them” which sounds really noble, but I would have injected bits of me into it -- intentionally or not. So I asked them to be themselves – but be as much themselves as they possibly could. I have a penchant for making ridiculous statements like that.

Who are you?

I didn’t know many of the people who showed up. I was suspicious that some of them were there to get a free professional portrait. There was a huge variety of people – some that looked to be as young as twelve; some looked to be close to seventy. Some came in drag, some with studded harnesses, some conventional, and even one with alien eyes.

As I shot, I listened. And what I heard was not what I was shooting. No one was what I thought my eyes and my camera told me. A bearded man who came in with his strikingly beautiful wife used to be a woman. The gender-fluid fashion model. The happily married gay soccer mom. The person born with both sets of plumbing, who doesn’t give a hoot what gender people think they are. As each person left I realized I could not assume who the next person would be. And that constantly trying to fit their narratives into something familiar and conventional tired me out. So I stopped trying.

Tilde

Back at work after that weekend, I was typing up business requirements, something like “must support ~8,000 users”. I use that squiggle a lot – called a tilde. It means approximately, or more or less. It’s the typographical equivalent of waving your hands in the air. As I looked at the tilde I nodded sagely, patted my monitor bezel, and thanked it for naming the exhibit: Tilde.

The title made each and every person’s story in the exhibit make perfect sense. No one is a deviation from the norm. If everyone is a tilde, there can be no absolute. We don’t have to struggle to fit their story into something we’re comfortable with if we just listen and accept their story. That inspired me to print out the hundred or so images and tape them to the exhibit wall. as is -- instead of the usual standardized framing. I’d gone this far without “packaging” them, and it seemed like the perfect final act of rebellion.

CONTENT_NAME: CGIS Staff Attends ESRI Developer Summit
TEXT:
By Diego Portillo

The Esri Developer Summit (DevSummit) is an annual event “For Developers, By Developers” that brings together software engineers, data scientists, and other professionals from around the world to learn, collaborate, and explore the latest developments in GIS technology. The summit takes place in March, on average more than 1,000 attendees from hundreds of public and private organizations as well as industries, have the opportunity to attend over 150 technical sessions, workshops, and hands-on training sessions, as well as engage with Esri experts and industry leaders. The conference showcases the latest GIS applications, tools, and services, providing attendees with insights into how GIS is being used.

Overall, the Esri DevSummit is a valuable event for anyone working in GIS development or interested in learning about the latest trends and innovations in GIS technology. It provides attendees with an opportunity to stay up-to-date with the latest developments in the field, as well as to connect with peers and experts in the industry. It has been several years since anyone form the CGIS team attended the summit, and we were able to take advantage of our Enterprise License Agreement with Esri and send 4 people.

They comeback with great insights of current GIS applications and uses, but also, and most importantly, with knowledge of what is coming up, what are the trends, Esri’s roadmap and vision. This information will be used to adjust the City of Portland GIS Geospatial Strategy.

Kellie Gulden: “ESRI continues to consolidate their mobile form app, ArcGIS Field Maps. Field Maps allows data capture and editing by streamlining critical workflows. Moving forward, ESRI is adding the ability to configure tasks with JSON and Arcade, reducing the complexity of creating and maintaining forms. Through Smart Camera Assistance, ESRI is integrating machine learning with images, and prepopulating attributes therefore reducing personnel time spent with data collection.

ESRI is adding a range of spatial analysis capabilities into the Map Viewer (browser based) providing the ability to combine data including Big Data with powerful analytical processing – reducing barriers to better understand data. This is the heart of GIS, and ESRI is increasing accessibility to technology and data.”

Derek Miller: “Esri’s proprietary expression language – Arcade – continues to gain traction throughout the ArcGIS system. Arcade allows developers to write lightweight, portable expressions that enhance or extend core functionality. These expressions can then be applied throughout ArcGIS applications, including custom applications developed with the ArcGIS  Maps SDK for Javascript. Arcade executes within profiles (think scope) that define the functionality exposed within a given context. Recent updates to the Form Constraint profile (feature editing) and multiple profiles exposed in the ArcGIS Dashboards product may provide enhanced functionality to our users.”

Aaron Kilbey: “The selection of web technologies for the front-end of the most recent version of PortlandMaps was a long and hard road circa 2014, most particularly because the ESRI JavaScript API which handles the spatial component, the map, and the evaluated CSS and JavaScript frameworks, the user-interface surrounding the map, at the time all had many difficulties participating together harmoniously to produce a responsive and universally accessible web application, such that quite a bit of code had to be written to make them play nicely together. 

For a newer version of PortlandMaps I’m trying to determine the best course forward with the currently available technologies, and, the thing at the Dev Summit that most piqued my interest was a product called Calcite.  The term itself has been around for years as the name of the theming system for ESRI Javascript API widgets, but, it has matured to the point that, as of January 2023, it has been released as a full-fledged CSS and Javascript framework.  Upon initial evaluation it contains all of the major capabilities and components that would be crucial if we were to extract our current solutions for CSS, JavaScript widgets and icons.  In theory, as this product has matured while always being bound to the ESRI JavaScript API map, it will seamlessly integrate with it, reducing the need for go-between code, while opening up potential deeper integration between the aspatial UI presentation layer and the map. 

Additionally, there was particular emphasis in Calcite sessions placed on the widescale efforts that ESRI took with the product in regard to accessibility and design, two communities that traditionally seemed underrepresented, and two of the most essential things to “get right” for modern web interfaces.”

Mike Quetel: “Portland has a large and busy deployment of ArcGIS Server, the engine behind PortlandMaps, MapWorks and many online maps, apps and dashboards.  This deployment  has grown substantially over the last few years and we expect the trend to continue.  As such CGIS keeps an eye on future offerings that may help us manage and scale to customer and project needs more effectively.

A new and exciting offering from Esri is a cloud native version of ArcGIS Server, built using Kubernetes and designed for deployment on Microsoft Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS), Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) and others.  Kubernetes “containerizes” data services and applications so that they may scale dynamically as demand ebbs and flows, while maintaining isolation from other workloads. Containers also tend to be relatively standalone. This means that dependencies exist within the container itself, easing the process of deployment from DEV, to TEST and finally into PROD.   We’ll continue to monitor this product’s evolution and how it may help us deliver additional value to customers going forward.”

If you would like to know more about GIS, what we learned from the Esri Dev Summit, or about the CGIS program, do not hesitate contact the CGIS team at maps@portlandoregon.gov or btscorpgis@portlandoregon.gov.

CONTENT_NAME: GIS in Action Conference Brings Regional Geographers to The Portland Building
TEXT:
By Andrew Neuman and Diego Portillo; Pictures by Diego Portillo and Paul Cone

If you noticed more maps and people in the Portland Building recently, it’s because the 31st annual GIS in Action Conference was held in the Portland Building during the week of April 17th. This conference is hosted by the Oregon URISA Chapter and the Cascadia Region chapter of the American Society of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing (ASPRS). The conference had over 200 registered attendees and an additional 50 volunteers, and professional sponsors. In addition, the conference offered day-long training workshops and provided over 50 presentations on various topics such as GIS Collaboration, Imagery Advancements, GIS Solutions for Public Utilities, and various technology focused presentations.

Team members from the Corporate GIS Team and other staff throughout the City of Portland helped coordinate, gave presentations, and volunteered their time to make this conference successful. Diego Portillo (CGIS Manager) championed the conference and coordinated with OMF Facilities to reserve the public spaces on the 1st and 2nd floor, coordinated the volunteers, and worked tirelessly before, after, and throughout the conference. Andrew Neuman (CGIS) also served on the planning committee and volunteered throughout the conference. Tommy Dong (CGIS) created the fantastic maps and signage that helped attendees navigate the building. Finally, James Apple (IS Manager, Communications) and his team provided technical support for all of the AV and computer needs for the conference, and we were so thankful for their assistance. Special thanks goes also to Kathy Thielen from Facilities Services for her patience and support getting the building ready, and last but not least, Jonah Willbach and all the 311 team that shared the front desk. We couldn’t have done this without everyone’s support. 

Former Governor John Kitzhaber delivered the keynote address and spoke to the theme of the conference of Interconnectedness to share stories on how GIS Technology can be utilized to help resolve issues such as houselessness and mitigation of wildfires.

The city had a very visible presence with its numerous volunteers and presenters from BTS, BES, PBOT, Water, and Planning and Sustainability. They delivered presentations showing the great work we do here at the City of Portland in GIS, data analysis, and visualization.

Finally, our very own CTO, Jeff Baer, delivered the closing keynote, sharing how vital GIS and maps are in our culture and how embedded GIS is in the City of Portland. In addition, Jeff provided some great examples of some of the work where GIS is used to help drive business decisions.

CONTENT_NAME: Active Shooter / Workplace Violence Preparedness
TEXT:
Warning:  Active Shooter videos are intense reenactments performed by actors. Some viewers may find this material disturbing or triggering. This training is voluntary.  

The BTS Safety Committee has put together a new site with links to resources to help you be more prepared in case you are ever confronted with an Active Shooter situation.  The time to think about what you would do in such a situation is before it occurs.  Many people freeze in this type of a situation.  Why?  Because they don’t know what to do.  Like most people, they haven’t thought about it. There are two videos. One produced by the FBI, the other through Homeland Security and Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA).  Each video goes through the options of Run, Hide, Fight.  If you were to run, where would you run? What path would you choose to get there to avoid as much of the danger as possible?  If you could not run because you are unable, or you don’t have a path to escape, where would you hide?  If you hide, what can you do to avoid being seen?  What can you do to make it more difficult for the shooter to get to you?   And if you have no options left, and you had to fight, what would you fight with?  Do you have items nearby that could be used as a weapon?  Should you enlist others around you to fight with you to maximize your odds of surviving? 

The two videos introduce you to these three options and provide you ideas for what your plan might look like.  Think about it now.  Then, if confronted with this type of situation, you choose your path and execute.  This will help you to avoid becoming an easy target.  These concepts are for home, in public places, or at work.

Additionally, there is a link to additional resources from the FBI. 

We have a link to Portland Police Resources including a 38-minute podcast by Officer Leo Harris on Community Active Shooter Preparedness.  We highly recommend you take the time to listen to this very informative podcast.

Finally, we have a link to Rose City Self-Defense.

Rose City Self-Defense empowers girls, women, and the LGBTQ+ community, with a focus on engaging communities of color, people with disabilities, folks with unstable housing, as well as safety for sex workers.

We introduce you to our new site at the link below:

On December 22nd we lost utility power to our Lookout Point radio site and the site did not switch to generator power as designed. Instead, it went to battery backup which only last for a few hours. They spent the day driving to the site. They had to cut through a couple of fallen trees with chainsaws, drive through snow, and eventually walk the last 1/4 mile to get to the site to switch the site over to the generator before the batteries ran out of power. The loss of this site would have compromised radio coverage in east Multnomah County first responders. Their dedication kept our Radio system operating, and no public safety professional lost coverage.

CONTENT_NAME: Hearing Impairments and Allyship – Part 3 of 3
TEXT:
In this 3-part series, Michael Powell (Stores) and Victoria Flagg (Transport Network) share their personal stories about their hearing impairments as well as tips on how you can be a better ally.

Part 1: Tips on how to be a better ally

Part 2: Description of their impairments

Part 3: How the pandemic changed things for them

Please know that any action you take to be a good ally goes a long way.

 

Question: Has the pandemic and remote working made communicating easier or harder for you?

Michael:

The pandemic has thrown me in to a very unique and awkward position where I found myself navigating hearing loss in a way I’ve never experienced before. Suddenly everyone’s face was covered, and I no longer had lip-reading to rely on. My “hearing” had disappeared overnight. Without knowledge of ASL, I was faced with the challenge of learning how to communicate with people around me all over again. Even a quick run to the grocery store became a daunting task. It was incredibly difficult, and it continues to be at times. I disliked venturing out into public and I became well acquainted with my new friend, Social Anxiety. Eventually I had to build up my confidence and learn how to advocate for myself more than I was used to when out there interacting with the world. When I started with BTS in November 2021, I was lucky enough to join a team of compassionate colleagues (HEY TPCS!!) that were very patient with me. Never have I experienced a workplace environment where my teammates were so understanding and willing to go the extra mile to help me get settled into my new position. It truly made a difference in my onboarding and I’m so incredibly grateful for them.

Victoria:

Pandemic style meetings have been a godsend for me! Assuming people are willing to use their cameras and close captioning, I am in heaven being able to hear most of what is said in a meeting. Pre-pandemic, being the remote person in an in-person meeting was 100% miserable. I might as well not call in because people didn’t sit close to the mic. Most of the time the extended mics weren’t even present. There was never video or close captioning. If I was attending in person, it was maybe 50% miserable, depending on the group of people. Folks would sit wherever they’d like (countertops, floor) and speak with no way for lip-readers to see. People even covered their mouths with their hands. At my last place of employment, I was the outspoken one for all the hearing-impaired. I can’t tell you how many times I shared after an all-staff meeting that I was unable to hear and why. (I shared in the beginning of all-staff meetings too). Usually that info was well received with promises for improvement. It took years before I ever witnessed any of the improvements and I had to keep speaking up.

CONTENT_NAME: Hearing Impairments and Allyship – Part 2 of 3
TEXT:
In this 3-part series, Michael Powell (Stores) and Victoria Flagg (Transport Network) share their personal stories about their hearing impairments as well as tips on how you can be a better ally.

Part 1: Tips on how to be a better ally

Part 2: Description of their impairments

Part 3: How the pandemic changed things for them

Please know that any action you take to be a good ally goes a long way.

 

Question: What is your impairment like and how did you get it?

Michael:

My hearing loss stems from birth. My mother contracted Rubella/German Measles during her pregnancy with me. This damaged the cochlea in my ears and the tiny little hairs inside that are responsible for picking up and recognizing different kinds of sounds. My hearing loss is considered a profound hearing loss. Without my hearing aid, sounds need to be so loud, it could very well damage a hearing person’s ears. I have an easier time recognizing lower frequencies than I do higher frequencies. If your face is covered or obstructed, I still can hear you. I just can’t make sense of the words you’re saying. It sounds like a foreign language or gibberish to me. That’s where the lip-reading skill comes in and fills in the blanks for me. My entire family is hearing so they raised me as a hearing person. In the 80’s there was this expectation that a deaf or hearing-impaired person would never amount to all the things that a normal, hearing person could. Because of that, my parents thought it was best that I went to school full time at the age of 3 to learn how to read lips and talk like a hearing person. In 2004 I attempted to get a cochlear implant in my left ear, and it failed horribly. I lost all the natural hearing I had in that ear and now I am down to just the one remaining and somewhat functioning ear.

Victoria:

I was born with my impairment but wasn't diagnosed until my early thirties. I can’t really explain why my “kid” self didn’t draw more attention to the issue. My closest friends all knew. No adults in my life knew and somehow my school system never tested me. I do recall one day in early grade school when I was tested for speech impairments, but I managed to talk the adult tester out of flagging me for special classes. I got by sitting in front of the class and fully embracing my nerd identity.

My mother has also been impaired all or most of her life. When I was a baby, my grandmother and mother did their own tests on me. The banged pots and pans to see if I would respond to the noise. I passed their test with flying colors, and they were satisfied that my hearing was “normal.”

One reason I might have stopped telling most people as a child is because I got so tired of people telling me that I just liked to make them repeat themselves. People dismissed my explanations that I could not hear them and would state that I just like to say, “what?” just to annoy them.

The reason I got tested in my early thirties was because my employer wanted a baseline test for me. My employer tested every year, and the baseline would serve to let them know if my hearing changed while employed there. As a telecommunications technician, I sometimes worked with equipment that could potentially damage my ears.

After stepping out of the audiology booth the day of my first test, the audiologist told me I needed to see an ENT. She also pointed out that I can’t “hear men well.” Weeks later, the audiologist confirmed that I had likely been born with my impairment and that it likely has never changed. She told me three other things:

1.  That I have what’s known as Cookie Bite. My last test looked like this:

 

2.  That people with far better hearing than me get hearing aids.

3.  Since I’ve been getting along without hearing aids, I didn’t absolutely need to get them yet.

She advised that a day would come that it bothered me that others were bothered that I couldn’t hear them. She said that’s when I should invest in the aides.

That day quickly came. After I had proof of what I’d known all along, I felt more justified saying, “what?” again. The two people closest to me at the time, my spouse and a coworker, started to get very annoyed. I got the aides to help put them out of their misery.

What is a “Cookie Bite” you ask? As you can see from my last test, I have perfect hearing at the very lowest frequency they test for and pretty much perfect hearing at the highest frequency. The high frequencies are what people tend to lose as they age or due to loud sounds. I likely can still hear those rings tones kids used to use so adults wouldn’t hear their cell phones ring in class.

Here are the different ranges:

  • Normal hearing: -10 to 20 dB
  • Mild hearing loss: 20 to 40 dB higher than normal
  • Moderate hearing loss: 40 to 70 dB higher than normal
  • Severe hearing loss: 70 to 90 dB higher than normal
  • Profound loss: 90 dB or more

Since my “loss” dips down to almost 70 dB, I usually describe my impairment as “moderately-severe.”

My tests have not changed over the years. Someday, I imagine my high frequencies will go. I do everything I can to protect my ears to help avoid that.

I miss syllables mostly. It means, even with hearing aids, my brain must work extra hard to fill in the gaps. This is why I will suddenly understand an entire sentence mid-way when someone complies with my request to repeat themself.

Another tidbit: When I was diagnosed with the Cookie Bite, most audiologists had never heard of such a thing. It’s only in the last several years that hearing aid technology has become sophisticated enough to correct for a Cookie Bite. Thus, audiologists now know.

CONTENT_NAME: Hearing Impairments and Allyship – Part 1 of 3
TEXT:
In this 3-part series, Michael Powell (Stores) and Victoria Flagg (Transport Network) share their personal stories about their hearing impairments as well as tips on how you can be a better ally.

  

Part 1: Tips on how to be a better ally

Part 2: Description of their impairments

Part 3: How the pandemic changed things for them

Please know that any action you take to be a good ally goes a long way.

Here are tips Michael and Victoria put together on how to be an ally for hearing impaired folks:

Please keep in mind that not every deaf/hearing impaired person has the same preferences.

In General:

  • Make (and keep) eye contact.
  • If we politely ask you to repeat yourself, please do not treat us like we didn’t understand you and treat us like we’re stupid. We are capable of understanding if we can hear what you are saying.
  • If we don’t respond to our name, or something you’ve said to us, please wave or do something to gently get our attention. For some hearing impaired, we may encourage you to tap us on the shoulder but please confirm that before trying that out.  It’s not ok to raise your voice, shout, or talk to us in a slow and condescending manner. Yes, this is something we go through way too often.
  • Do not talk over others because we can only read one set of lips at a time. Our hearing aids likely can’t sort out the competing conversations despite how much better the tech has become.
  • If there’s a word or phrase that we’re having a difficult time understanding, choosing a different word or re-phrasing always helps. Jotting the word or phrase down on a notepad is also helpful.
  • Use written communication to ensure complex topics are fully understood by everyone on the team.  Consider using chat windows and emails to follow up after important verbal communication.
  • Phone conversations for most hearing impaired are especially challenging. Some of us have assistive technology for this but there are still limitations and challenges.  People on the other line are generally not that accommodating or understanding. Oftentimes they say they’re “Not interested” and hang up on us. Please consider using video chat with hearing impaired. If in an office environment where the phone is ringing, offer to be the one to answer the phone.
  • “Reading Lips” isn’t just about reading lips. It uses the whole lower half of the face. For example, depending on the sounds being vocalized, a chin moves up and down or cheek muscles change the face shape in different ways.  Therefore, transparent masks at their best, when they don’t fog up, are like trying to read a book with a single tealight candle. It’s better than no light at all, but it doesn’t mean it’s an effortless experience.
  • When practicing good mask wearing techniques, don’t pull your mask down when you realize a hearing-impaired person can’t hear you. Find a mask-friendly way to communicate.

Video Calls:

  • Turn on your video so hearing-impaired people can see both your lips and your body language.
  • If you are hosting a Zoom or WebEx meeting, make sure the closed captioning feature is enabled before starting the meeting so attendees can utilize this feature.
  • Turn on the closed captioning feature for yourself so you can see if it captures your words accurately.
  • If you’re hosting a training on Zoom, let attendees in early so they can set up their audio. Hearing impaired folks may need more time to set up their audio and will miss valuable early meeting time if you let them in just as the meeting starts. Try to let them in at least ten minutes ahead of time.
  • Encourage others to turn on their cameras and use closed captioning.
  • Encourage the use of the chat window to follow up after important/complex verbal communications.
  • Encourage the use of the chat window for icebreakers and other social interactions where multiple people may be inclined to all chat at once.

In-Person Meetings:

  • If attending an in-person meeting, make sure your mouth is visible to all attendees and speak to be heard. Don’t turn your back and only talk to the person beside you. If there are microphones, use them.
  • If you’re a speaker at an in-person event or meeting, when you get to the podium don’t dismiss the mic and then ask (without using the mic) if everyone can hear you. That singles people out in your audience. Many people with far better hearing than ours will not be able to hear you and will be too shy to tell you when put on the spot like that.

In Summary:

  • Know that any action you take to be a good ally goes a really long way. We realize we must advocate for ourselves but it’s exhausting.

CONTENT_NAME: Aaron Johnson - Game Changer
TEXT:
By Erin Poole and James Apple

Introducing a new award for BTS staff members who look to implement innovate ideas that enhance our services offerings while reducing costs to customers, and we’re calling it the Game Changer award.

 

The award name derives from our first recipient, Aaron Johnson.

 

In 2018, Aaron, attended the ISC West Security Conference in Las Vegas. While touring product offerings on the show floor, he identified a new cable made by Paige Datacom called “GameChanger”.

 

The marketing materials claimed it could easily exceed current Ethernet standards defined in IEEE 802.3*. Recognizing the advantage of this cable in reducing the complexity needed for cable runs exceeding 300 feet, Aaron recommended on his return they give it a try. The vendor was contacted and we inquired about testing this cable out. Paige Datacom was very excited and quickly got the product to us, adding in connectors and crimpers for free to help offset the cost of shipping.

 

The team installed a camera using this new cable at a PBOT facility, about 700 feet of it. Typically, this install would have required fiber and power to accommodate the long distance, media converters to switch back to copper at both ends, all adding potential multiple points of failure in the future. The new GameChanger cable worked as advertised and the Video Team has been using it since this first test run, with zero issues.

 

Aaron’s recommendation has seriously been a “Game Changer” for the BTS Video Team and how we engineer our installations. In 2019, Paige Datacom received their patent for this new product and instantly became a coveted item among low voltage security contractors. The Video Team added the GameChanger cable to its toolkit and has greatly reduced video installation complexity and associated costs for our Bureau customers. Return on investment, the cost of the conference, was achieved in the first installation.   

Nice work Aaron, thank you for your innovative thinking!

 

*Footnote on patent

CONTENT_NAME: Melody Fisher - SuperStar
TEXT:
By Shawna Graber

The BTS Recognition Committee was formed in 2016 and quickly launched the SuperStar award to show appreciation for BTS individuals who demonstrated exceptional customer service, peer support, or work product. Several recipients have received this award over the years, but we took a snooze during the pandemic as it made for personal handoff a bit difficult. Now we are back with the latest SuperStar!

Thank you, Melody!

TEXT:

Please take a moment to view a short newsletter about P&D on our Portland.Gov page here.

 

P&D remains available to assist with your printing/scanning/copying as well as your mailroom/pickup & delivery service needs!  Do not hesitate to contact me or my team with any questions or new projects.
