CONTENT_NAME: Interview with Juan Carlos, OMF Racial Equity Program Manager
TEXT:
By BTS Equity Committee

The BTS Equity Committee is happy to share an interview we did with OMF’s new Racial Equity Program Manager, Juan Carlos Ocaña-Chíu. Read below to find out a little about him and his plans for making OMF a more Equitable workplace.

Ice Breaker Questions

1)      What tech device can you not live without?

  • My personal iphone, for sure

2)      What is your favorite dish to eat or cook?

  • Tofu and broccoli with ginger sauce

3)      Do you have any pets?

  • No, but I love cats (other pets are good, too)

4)      What’s your favorite Portland sports team?

  • The Thorns and Timbers

 

Equity Questions

1)      What do you see as the role of individual bureau Equity Committees in your bigger, immediate goals/initiatives?

Advancing racial equity is part of everybody’s work at the City of Portland. City Council made the policy decision to lead with racial equity and anti-racism. That means that everything we do as public servants needs to have a positive, racial equity and anti-racist impact, and improve the lives of Black, Indigenous and people of color (BIPOC) communities and other historically and continually marginalized communities. The equity committees, like the one at the Bureau of Technology Services (BTS), have a key role in advancing racial equity. Equity committees know their bureaus best and can help find the best ways to implement racial equity and anti-racist work internally. They can also generate new ideas that are more specific and appropriate for their bureaus, and create concrete opportunities for bureau staff to get involved in this crucial work. I’m really excited to see that BTS has an active equity committee that is supported by leadership. I look forward to learning more about the committee’s work and being a resource for you in having greater racial equity and anti-racism impacts.

 

2)      What is one initiative/goal you hope to have running this year?

I am working on a few initiatives that I want to launch during my first year as the OMF racial equity program manager, and there is one that is especially important to me. I want to work with folks in BTS and in other bureaus and teams in the Office of Management and Finance (OMF) to find great examples of how our work has a positive racial equity impact on BIPOC communities. In my short time on this job, I have heard many folks at OMF talk about how they provide services to other City employees. And while this is true, I strongly believe we need to make the connection about how these services have an impact in the community at large. I believe that everything BTS staff, and all OMF staff, do contributes to making life better for Portlanders. So I want to work with the racial equity committee and everybody else in the bureau, to find those stories, polish them, and start telling them to ourselves and to the public. I am sure we will find some amazing stories that we can proudly share.

 

3)      How do you think Technology impacts equity?

Information technology (IT) is foundational for almost everything we do on this day and age. Communications, work, learning, entertainment, wellbeing, you name it. It all relies on IT to run smoothly. And like any technology, IT has the potential to be used to advance greater racial equity or to work against it. It is our responsibility as public servants to ensure that we use IT for the benefit of all Portlanders, and not just of the groups that have traditionally enjoyed those benefits. Working toward digital inclusion is the best way how we at BTS and all of OMF can ensure that the benefits of current IT are available to all communities in our city, especially to those that have been traditionally excluded from them. The COVID-19 pandemic has also made it easier to provide IT tools and capacity to expand digital inclusion in the form of new ways for Portlanders to interact with their municipal government to request and receive services, to learn about City work and initiatives, and to participate in the governance of our city. If we continue to apply an intersectional racial equity lens to how we provide IT tools and services, we can realize the promise of technology as a powerful tool to expand opportunity and improve outcomes for BIPOC and other historically and continually marginalized communities.

 

4)      What advice would you give to somebody who is new to approaching their work through a racial equity lens? Where might they start?

We each bring our particular experiences and backgrounds to our work. We are also all situated differently by virtue of our job titles and classifications, racial and gender identities, ability status, sexual orientation, income, class, and many other characteristics. We have privilege because of some of our characteristics, and we experience oppression because of others. I recommend that folks new to racial equity work reflect on their identities, especially racial identity, in terms of privilege and oppression: where do they benefit and where they are oppressed. Folks who have traditionally had privilege should do their own research and reflect on the systems that give them privilege and how they benefit from them. Ideally, they should also reflect on what they can do to contribute to changing those systems. I strongly recommend against folks with privilege asking their relatives, colleagues and/or friends who experience oppression to teach them about those systems of oppression and their struggle. For example, I experience oppression as an immigrant of color in this country, but I also experience privilege as a cisgender, straight man with a decent income. It is my personal responsibility to educate myself about the struggles of folks that experience oppression in the areas where I have privilege, and to find ways for me to be a better ally to them. There are a number of resources where we can all learn about oppression and how to be better allies to support the struggle for liberation that our relatives, colleagues and communities are going through. A great place to start learning about racial equity is this Equity Resources webpage by the City’s own Office of Equity and Human Rights. The Office also offers excellent trainings to City staff on racial equity, like the Racial Equity 101 class.

CONTENT_NAME: Printing and Distribution (P&D) Assessment Report Summary
TEXT:
By Matthew Spitulski and Bryan Pirrello

February 2022

The Bureau of Technology Services (BTS) contracted with Synergy Resources Group (SRG) to perform an independent assessment of P&D’s operations, trends before and during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as projections for customer utilization in the next 2-5 years.

Critical elements of the assessment included:

• Financial analysis: customer utilization, services utilization and in bureau copier utilization.

• Interviews: P&D staff, Bureau operations managers, Bureau staff with direct contact with P&D.

• Customer survey

• Market review: Comparing printing rates and services in both the public and private sectors.

• OMF’s 2021 Rate study: Utilized applicable information to support the assessment. Based on the analysis, SRG presented key findings and recommendations along with a scenario to support BTS and the P&D division in determining the best path forward.

Next Steps:

• Share Summary and Report with P&D Staff

• Provide P&D Staff the opportunity to meet individually with SRG and/or Matthew and Bryan to ask questions

• Draft Frequently Asked Questions and Communications for staff, stakeholders, and customers

• Implementation planning

Key findings:

• Overall, there has been a significant disruption in printing needs due to the pandemic, with 33% drop in revenue between the fiscal year (FY) 18-19 and FY20-21.

• According to customer interviews and surveys, most do not expect print volumes to return to pre pandemic volumes. More likely customers expect an increase from current levels.

• Customers value P&D staff procuring printing services for jobs that are outside the division’s scope, specialty and capacity to execute in the print shop.

• Distribution and Mail Services may be the most stable in terms of bureaus keeping utilization levels consistent from current and pre-pandemic levels.

• In-Bureau Copier services are likely to continue their downward trend, due to behavioral changes as a result of the pandemic and future plans for City staff continuing to work remotely.

• Only a small percentage of P&D public sector peers nationwide have centralized printing services. Most departmental/agency budgets cover the cost of printing and delivery.

• P&D staff possess many other skills which include the ability to provide quality customer service, prioritize tasks, manage workflow, work as a team, and perform on a deadline.

Key Recommendations: Note that BTS Leadership has committed that no current P&D staff will lose their job as a result of implementing any recommendations.

• Continue to right size the division as print and mail volumes become more apparent, in the years to come, through attrition, in bureau transfers or new hires.

• Consider an external management service to manage the in-bureau copiers with functionality that includes the ability to “pull” a print job or use a copier anywhere in the City. Bureaus pay the vendor on a per-sheet basis.

• Develop formal agreements with private sector commercial printing businesses to provide the print services outside of P&D’s scope, specialty, and equipment. Bureau operations managers are expecting the FY2021-22 rate increase to be adjusted down after last year’s increase. With a $1.5 million decline in revenue from 2019-20 to the forecasted 2021-22 revenue, it will be important to evaluate a rate adjustment downward.

• Explore upgrading online ordering software to increase online orders.

• Based on effects of the pandemic and increase in digitation, minimize investment in new print shop equipment.

• Explore route optimization software and efficiencies to delivery routes.

CONTENT_NAME: BTS Blog – Path to Leadership
TEXT:
By Melissa Mills and Elonda Bristol

Path to Leadership is a values-based leadership program that prepares emerging City leaders for supervisory roles. Elonda Bristol and Melissa Mills graduated in April, having completed the 9-month program. HR has announced they are beginning recruitment for the next cohort. You can go to NeoGov to apply for the 2022/2023 program through May 17th.

Path to Leadership provides an opportunity for developing your leadership skills through the lens of the City’s core values – Anti-Racism, Collaboration, Communication, Equity, Fiscal Responsibility, and Transparency. This isn’t a management program where you are going to learn to how to make fancy excel sheets to keep up with the minutia of daily activities (although if you are interested in improving your excel skills check out QuickHelp!). Participants attend trainings, are put through thought exercises, and learn from each other through discussion. Numerous experts gave trainings on equity, leadership style, personal successes and failures within their careers, how to take negative feedback, and creating a work/life balance.  You are given possible work scenarios and talk through them with peers while applying the City’s values. Listening to how peers would handle situations opens your mind to different approaches.

The program ends with presenting an Impact Project. Melissa’s group presented on how best to create an inclusive work environment for field employees and Elonda’s group looked at how to recruit and retain employees of color.

 

Melissa’s Highlight

My favorite part of the program was the connections I made with employees from other bureaus. I think we all know silos exist and are hard to overcome. It can be hard to know what other BTS teams are up too, let alone other groups within the City.

 

Elonda’s Highlight

I really enjoyed the opportunity to be a part of this learning experience.  The highlight, however, and as Melissa mentioned, was developing connections with employees from other bureaus and being able to hear their successes and struggles as they build their careers with the City.  There are rarely opportunities for us to branch from our own bureaus to develop working relationships if we aren’t on a project or assignment together.  Meeting other employees and building relationships was key to being successful in the program and I believe those relationships and that foundation will also be paramount to a successful career with the City.  

If you have an interest in leadership, it’s 100% worth your time to go through this program!

CONTENT_NAME: Extreme Makeover - SAP Edition!
SUMMARY_TEXT: A blog article about the SAP HANA Migration Project
TEXT:
By HANA Project Team

The Bureau of Technology Services migrated the City’s SAP applications from Oracle database to SAP HANA database on December 5th, 2021. The initiative to migrate the database were based on several key business drivers, including some of the following.

  • The current implementation of SAP was launched in 2008 and requires a strategic infrastructure refresh to set the platform up for the next 5-7 years.
  • Platform refresh supports the City’s SAP Strategic Roadmap which the TESC - Technology Executive Steering Committee approved in 2019.
  • Allows the City to best utilize the existing investment in SAP to support future opportunities to expand beyond a tradition ERP system.
  • Oracle databases are out of support.
  • Moves SAP off the more expensive AIX server platform to Unix/Red Hat reducing costs.

The migration took an entire weekend, from 5 PM on Friday, December 3rd to 11 AM on Sunday, December 5th to complete the production cutover. It was a two-phase project, started with a design phase which was completed with the purchasing of the hardware in 2020. The implementation phase was scheduled to follow right after the delivery of the hardware, but was delayed until April 2021, due to the interruption of COVID19. It was a multi-team project led by Enterprise Business Solution (EBS) division, and spanning most, if not all areas in BTS. The migration touched several infrastructure, software, users, and processes across the city, from check printing, payroll processing, and vendor invoicing.

In addition to the key business drivers, the new HANA servers provide faster processing and improve reporting performance. Users of the new HANA database applications have already seen great improvement. Below are some of the statistics gathered before and after the migration.

With HANA, we can implement new Human Capital Management (HCM) applications, such as Employee Central which provides the breadth of HCM functionality, and S/4HANA to enhance and transform critical enterprise functions, ranging from financial accounting to procurement. This initiative aligns with the strategic roadmap for the City of Portland to best utilize our existing investment in SAP by positioning us to move forward with technology that enable a whole host of benefits.

CONTENT_NAME: Highlighting Equity Work Outside BTS
TEXT:
Photo Courtesy: City of Portland, Bureau of Equity & Human Rights

By BTS Equity Committee

The BTS Equity Committee is a small part of the City of Portland’s Equitable Workplace Vision. We provide Quarterly Bureau Equity Sessions, training opportunities, and review of internal policies, but the City has many resources and programs. An exciting update is that OMF now has its own Racial Equity Program Manager, Juan Carlos Ocaña-Chíu! We look forward to learning from and collaborating with Juan Carlos. I hope you had a chance to read Tom Rinehart’s email on January 5th welcoming Juan Carlos and outlining his priorities.

 

In this blog post, we would like to highlight the Diverse and Empowered Employees of Portland. DEEP is a City of Portland employee-driven program that supports a creative and inclusive work environment. They provide mentoring, education, leadership, and networking opportunities.

 

DEEP does an excellent job of producing educational material. Perhaps some of you have this link on your email or have seen it “Why pronouns are listed in my signature?.” For some transgender and gender non-binary people, pronouns are an important part of expressing identity. Listing pronouns helps normalize gender discussion. We are all on the same team and being respectful and creating a safe work environment is something we all deserve.

 

One of the coolest projects DEEP oversees is the Affinity Groups. Affinity Groups are voluntary employee-led groups that share a particular protected class such as race, disability, ethnicity, gender, or sexual orientation. Please look through the eleven, soon to be twelve groups and see if there are any of interest to you! To be a part of an affinity group, sign up to be on an email list at www.portlandoregon.gov/deep/signup. Paid time is available for attending meetings, as well as other Affinity Group leadership and volunteer activities.

 

DEEP and the Affinity Groups have partnered with City Council members and led many positive changes at the City over the years. A few of the projects that you may recognize are the Lactation Rooms led by PDX City Parents; Trans Healthcare and All User Restrooms, led by LGBTQIA+ & Friends; partnerships with LGBTQIA+ & Friends and Women’s Empowerment on expanded Bereavement Leave policies; City African American Network (CAAN) writing, distributing, and continuing to lead efforts regarding the City’s Black Workforce and disparities for these employees.

 

In 2022, DEEP is in the process of launching its Leadership Development Program for Affinity Groups with a focus on Black, Indigenous, and People of Color employees. Keep an eye out for communications on this exciting opportunity.

 

Having an inclusive and kind work environment benefits us all. Fair treatment no matter protected class, clears the way for us to show up and do our jobs.

CONTENT_NAME: City of Portland Wins Versaterm Innovation Award
TEXT:
By Paul Cone 

Earlier this month I traveled to Tampa, Florida to attend the annual Versaterm Users Workshop.  This is an annual event hosted by Versaterm, who is the City’s vendor for the CAD (Computer Aided Dispatch) and RMS (Records Management System).  CAD is the BOEC 911 dispatch system, and also includes the MDT (Mobile Display Terminal) system that is used for all city and county emergency response agencies in Multnomah County.  RMS is the records system used by Portland Police – the RegJIN system.  In 2020 I worked with Miranda Wood, who was then a crime analyst with PPB, to develop a solution for School Safety Emergency Management.  We submitted our solution for the Versaterm Public Safety Innovation Award, and won first place, which included an all-expenses paid trip for two of us to attend the conference.  We were originally scheduled to go to the conference in Saskatoon last year, but it was canceled.  (And after watching this video that they showed at the end of this year's conference, promoting next year's conference, back at Saskatoon, I must say I'm a bit disappointed.)  So this year I went to represent BTS and BOEC, and Officer Tony Marley went to represent PPB, as Miranda is now with BES. 

Through Miranda’s work with the PPB School Resource Officer program, and my work with the BOEC dispatch system, we learned that there is information about schools that could be useful in an emergency, but it was not easily accessible by all responders who might need it.  Major emergency events in schools are infrequent, but the need for rapid and coordinated responses across multiple agencies is essential.  The availability and consistency of school contact information and floor plans were not synchronized across public safety agencies. 

Our solution was to set up a process to compile existing information about schools, their location, their administrative staff (e.g. principals, vice principals, school secretaries), develop consistent critical incident plans, and then share the files in a way that all responders could access it easily.  This is done through the MapViewer software component of the CAD and MDT systems.  

We did of course encounter challenges, such as resistance to technology, inconsistencies with school floor plan quality, and of course with the loss of the SRO program, we are working to figure out a new data collection process.  But we are up to the challenge and plan on rolling out an update school data later this fall. 

Here is the link to our PowerPoint presentation that we made at the conference.

CONTENT_NAME: BTS HelpDesk: Pandemic Edition
TEXT:
By Victor Cabunoc

Much like our peers throughout the city, the BTS HelpDesk had to make significant changes to the way we operated after the pandemic hit. Despite the initial learning curve associated with adjusting to remote work, the HelpDesk has found creative solutions to not only replicate the level of work Pre-Covid, but also improve in some key areas.

 

Pictured: An empty bullpen area where HD1 (HelpDesk Level 1) once took calls.

The biggest change to our operations was the transition from working in-person at the office to working remotely. Historically, the BTS HelpDesk seldom teleworked because we did not have a method to answer support calls without a physical Avaya desk phone & handset. However, thanks to the Telecom team's rapid response, we now have Avaya softphones installed on our computers and can answer HelpDesk calls from home.

 

Pictured: A tray of RSA hardware tokens

Not only did the way we answer phone calls change, but the types of calls themselves changed drastically as well. Our team had never supported this many teleworking customers in the past. RSA Tokens were flying off the shelves to the point where our vendor had difficulties keeping up with demand.

Providing technical assistance to customers in a new VPN environment while working remotely posed challenges such as:

  • The average length of a phone call is longer due to the dependence on VPN to do basic troubleshooting tasks (something we didn’t give much thought to when most of us were physically connected to the same network)
  • Troubleshooting VPN connectivity issues in general
  • Instructing customers how to connect to VPN with their authentication method (Hardware/Software token or Tokenless)
  • Having consideration for every customers’ unique home set up
  • Not having direct physical access to leads or other coworkers (the HelpDesk bullpen) to look over our shoulders at a problem
  • No existing processes in place for our new environment

Despite the loss of a physical collaborative space where we can ask questions or communicate directly with each other, we have found that embracing Microsoft Teams has improved this aspect of collaboration. Being able to have information and questions flow through dedicated channels has increased responsiveness and visibility from the leads and other HD1 members. This, in turn, allows us to assist our customers faster than the conventional “over the cube wall” method. This is a change that we have welcomed and will most likely continue to use moving forward. 

Another significant improvement relates to the newfound culture that Support Center management has been promoting which is to “use your best judgement” and that “making a mistake is ok.” Early in the pandemic, management and leads had their capabilities stretched and didn’t have answers readily available for all the things that had popped up. HD1 members, specifically, had to rely more on guidelines and were encouraged to choose the best course of action for their trouble ticket. This has instilled confidence in some HD1 members to take initiative and promote a culture of incrementally getting better through mistakes.

 

 

Pictured: The outside of the 1900 building along SW 4th avenue. Empty – Normally filled with students, members of the public, and city employees.

 

Despite enjoying the shorter commute times, we all miss each other as interactions via online do not hold up to in-person interaction. I, personally, long for the day when Portland’s streets are filled once again with bustling crowds and we can all safely return to see our coworkers.

CONTENT_NAME: Microsoft Audio Licenses
TEXT:
Several Bureaus in the City opted for their users who did not previously have an Microsoft Audio license to participate in a promotional offer from Microsoft which added thousands of free Audio licenses to our account.

 

Why would I want an MS Audio license?

This may be just what you never knew you wanted… If you ever schedule meetings in Outlook, whether with just one other customer, peer, or manager/supervisor, or with a group of folks, MS audio will add a nice call-in option for all attendees. This comes in handy if one of the attendees doesn’t have access to a computer or the Teams apps as it lets them join the meeting with any phone. It also is useful where an attendee is having bandwidth/connection or audio issues. That person can still use a computer for the video part of the meeting in Teams while using a phone for audio so they have the full screen-sharing experience with better sound.

Here is how Audio looks in a meeting:

 

But Teams meetings weren’t so great last time I tried it! What if I prefer Zoom or another platform?

While Teams was already awesome for 1-on-1 meetings or for small groups, it did have some limitations at the beginning of this pandemic that made people choose other meeting platforms. If you haven’t checked it out lately, I invite you to give it another chance. Microsoft has made a number of significant improvements to their program over the last year-and-a-half including hosting large meeting sizes and facilitating break-out rooms. And unlike the other meeting platforms, you don’t have to pay extra to use Teams because it is included with your Office 365 account.

 

I’ve never used Teams much, how do I learn how to use Teams better?

If you haven’t used Teams yet, there is so much more to it than meetings. It would be well worth your time to learn more about using this collaboration and productivity environment.

Here are a few ways to get started:

  • QuickHelp includes some great training and is delivered in small increments so you can easily go through it at your own pace without missing where you left off
  • There are specific help articles to be found if you search on the BTS Technology Help Portal
  • There are numerous resource, tips-n-tricks, articles, and videos you can find with a quick internet search
  • Ask others in BTS how they use Teams

What if I don’t end up using my MS Audio license?

That is perfectly fine. You have the option to use it because you have a free license now, but there is no obligation. If you don’t end up using it, then we will not renew your MS Audio license in 2024. If you retire or otherwise move on between now and then, your license will automatically be returned to the license pool. This is a no-risk opportunity so give it a try on your next Teams meeting.

CONTENT_NAME: To The Top of Goat Mountain – Portland’s highest Public Safety radio site
TEXT:
By Kevin Novak

 

Critical repair work was completed at our Goat Mountain location in late February that necessitated a trip by snowmobile to the site by Kelly Bond and Kevin Novak of BTS’s Public Safety Technology Division.  Work was hampered by the fact that the area is located within the vicinity to where the wildfires of 2020 burned.  The forest service has temporarily closed access to the public to the area until mid-summer due to possible landslides.  After the arrival of the rangers to open the gate we proceeded on wet pavement to where the snowline was and prepared to transfer our tools and equipment to a snowmobile sled – but not before placing it all into thick trash bags to keep everything dry.

 

Before departing,  we all received a job briefing on safety equipment, use of the snowmobiles, and hand signals.  Then it was time to dawn our thick jackets, helmets, and gloves and begin up the mountain.  The road at the beginning was a bit rough with patches of asphalt and light snow, but then after about 5 minutes we proceeded onto thick enough snow where the snowmobiles could really do their job well!  Our final turn off the main road to the site, about a mile and a half, was where we encountered the thickest snowfall on this last, steep ascent.  The thin ‘canyon’ the trees created allowed the winters snow to pile up and remain – with thicknesses approaching 3-4 feet.

Once at the site the task of just opening the security fence was a challenge - not to mention keeping a careful lookout for falling ice/snow from the towers that were basking in the warm sunlight.  After making it inside the facility we proceeded to repair our radio infrastructure, and to warm up.  We swapped on-site equipment to begin the process of restoring radio service, verified the equipment was functioning, and packed up our gear and proceeded back down the hill in the cold and darkening skies to our vehicles for the drive back to the shop.

 

At 4,140 feet in elevation, the Goat Mountain site is just one of several locations in Multnomah, Clackamas, Clark, and Skamania counties the City maintains its mission-critical 800MHz P25 2-way radio communications technology to provide overlapping coverage for its operations and customers.

CONTENT_NAME: Updated BTS Outage Communication Process
TEXT:
By Elyse Rosenberg

What is the Issue?

Have you ever asked yourself:

  • How do customer bureaus get notified when a BTS service fails?
  • Why does it take so long for outage notifications to be sent?
  • Can I get an update on an outage without delaying the repair work?
  • Yeah, I’m having that problem too!  Should I do anything?

 Answering these questions and other similar ones has been challenging because we needed a more simplified, streamlined process with a clearer definition of roles.  We intuitively knew what needed to be done, but the road to get there may have been different based on who took ownership of the situation.

How Did We Respond?

A team was created to look at the existing process and recommend changes.  The goals of the team were:

  • A clear, simplified, and repeatable process
  • Well defined roles and responsibilities
  • More timely announcement of service impacting outages
  • Effective announcements, updates, and closure

The team studied outages from across the bureau in an attempt to identify inefficiencies and lessons learned.  There were key findings that the team was able to use, along with some best practice guidelines, to identify specific changes.

What was the Result of Our Effort?

The team identified four key roles necessary for each outage and a detailed plan to effectively communicate outages to leadership, to employees within BTS, and outward to bureaus and other consumers of BTS services. BTS Leadership and each service-owning team have been briefed and given the opportunity to learn and practice the new process. This updated BTS Service Outage Communication Process document will be the formal plan for communicating outages going forward.

With these process improvements you should see:

  • More timely announcements about outages that all come from the BTS HelpDesk e-mail account;
  • A clear and consistent format for the message that provides the known impact of the outage in addition to identifying what service is affected;
  • Status updates on the Technology Portal, at least once per day, and more often when significant information is discovered.

Future Improvements

We recognize that this will be an iterative process that continues to evolve to meet the demands of those affected by unplanned service outages.  As the process is perfected, the team will be looking to extend the functionality to 1) after-hour outages;  2) assist service owners who have traditionally managed their own communication process (EBS, Public Safety, and Non-BTS teams); and 3) clarify the process for cloud service outages currently owned by a vendor.

CONTENT_NAME: Corporate GIS Program Rolls Out New Version of MapWorks
TEXT:
By Matt Freid

The Corporate GIS Program released a new version of its MapWorks application over the last few months to give city staff access to a broad range of GIS and related tabular datasets.   MapWorks has been part of the city GIS environment for over 15 years and the new version retains all the popular features that users depend on while taking advantage of new functionality available from ESRI, the city’s GIS vendor.  

What is MapWorks?

The MapWorks application is completely designed, programmed and deployed by CGIS staff in partnership with GIS professionals working in bureaus throughout the City.  The intent of the application is to provide a light GIS client that allows users to query and interact with spatial data directly along with a set of productivity tools used to help automate common tasks.   Users can use the tools to access yearly air photo flights going back to the mid 90’s, search for properties, find intersections and select features by creating buffers or ad hoc polygons.   MapWorks also uses data from API’s created for Portlandmaps to integrate non spatial datasets like permits and assessor information, scanned documents tied to GIS features and even create formatted mailing lists for any area.   MapWorks has a familiar desktop GIS interface but with a simplified set of menus and toolbars to make it easy to learn and use.   

MapWorks 3.0

The newest version of MapWorks replaces two earlier versions with a completely reworked codebase.   The previous version relied on documents authored in an older version of ESRI’s desktop software, was cumbersome to install and used development tools that were no longer supported.  It also required connection to CGIS SQL Servers to access data or used large local datasets which meant it did not work well outside the city network.

The new version utilizes the latest ESRI Runtime SDK and a more contemporary programming framework making it easy to install and update.  The Runtime SDK also has a free tier which means that MapWorks so it can be used as widely as possible without increasing licensing costs.   Most importantly it uses web-based data provided through spatially enable REST endpoints assembled in web maps and distributed through an on-premise GIS content management system.  This allows users to access data anywhere they have a web connection – at work, at home or in the field.    Additionally, there is a set of web applications that allow GIS support staff to customize the set of maps available to workgroups, control access to tools and track usage.

This new architecture proved particularly important when the city moved to full time telework for thousands of staff members on short notice earlier this year.  Building on these new architectural structures a new version was deployed that allowed users to install the application on any Windows machine, receive automatic updates and access GIS data without a VPN connection or administrative privileges.  This has helped keep city staff productive working in this new work environment while decreasing the load on our VPN infrastructure.

If you are interested in learning more about MapWorks you can access the user guide at https://www.portlandmaps.com/apps/gcx/documents/mapworks/MapWorks_3_User_Guide.pdf .

This project was a true team effort that involved everyone in the CGIS Program as well as Vertical Applications staff working in the bureaus.  I’d like to thank – Mike Quetel, Mitch Vanderperren, Ryan Chen, Kellie Gulden, Aaron Kilbey, Paul Cone, Tammy Dong, and Trevor Smith as well as Jake Brown and Andrew Neuman in Vertical Applications.

CONTENT_NAME: My Week at the Emergency Coordination Center (ECC) as Incident Commander
TEXT:
By Jeff Baer

As Incident Commander you are involved in all the various sections from logistics, coordination, planning, operations, finance, safety, and public information. There are many moving pieces to working in the operations center and a large part of it involves being able to triage and assign issues to different sections to follow up and coordinate a response. It’s an open floor and many breakout rooms to work through issues as they come forward.

The ECC is organized around the FEMA Incident Command System. If you are interested in learning more about this, please visit the FEMA website at:

https://training.fema.gov/is/courseoverview.aspx?code=IS-100.c

The day starts off with signing in, getting your temperature taken, washing your hands and making sure your workstation is cleaned and ready for use. You then begin a series of meetings starting with a Command Staff meeting to find out what new information or events have happened overnight and discuss what may be coming up during the day followed by a staff briefing from each Section Chief. Sometimes you are tracking people down, scheduling meetings, attending meetings, making phone calls, finding who has answers to questions, following up to receive a status report and of course reading and replying to emails. At the end of the day you finish with a report out from each Section Chief on what they worked on which then gets placed in a daily events log or situation status report. The day goes by very quickly. Working in the ECC has been educational and provided opportunities for collaboration with other bureaus. It was an honor and a privilege to be the Incident Commander for a week and to work with so many dedicated individuals who are helping us through this crisis.

Please consider applying for an ECC position and talk to your manager. Not only will you learn new skills, but you’ll also become much more knowledgeable about the City’s role in responding to this crisis.

If you have any questions or concerns they can’t answer please contact:

ECCResourceUnit@portlandoregon.gov.

CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight Business Solutions Division Fall - 2019
TEXT:
The BTS Business Solutions Division delivers innovative application services that allow customers to meet business objectives. The dedicated Business Solutions teams are often on the nexus between business and technology doing meaningful work that is frequently challenging and rewarding.

In delivering digital services the Business Solutions team supports users in every City bureau as well as the community who engage with the City via hundreds of applications. The following updates from the Business Solutions teams that showcase the diversity and innovation of technologies being delivered by the division.

Portland Oregon Website Replacement POWR – Rick Nixon

The POWR project, one of the City’s top 3 technology projects, was started in January 2018 and is expected to continue through December 2020. The goal of the POWR project is to retire our aging in-house developed content management system and associated technologies with that of a proven world-class platform called Drupal. Drupal is a free and open-source content management framework used for more than a million websites across the globe, including government websites, ranging from the governments of Australia to Multnomah County right here at home.

The vision of the POWR project is to build a website for our community where services and information are easy to find, access, and understand. 'Easy to find' will rely on much improved search and browsing capabilities. 'Easy to access' not only refers to ADA compliance for assistive technologies, but also by device type, of which, mobile represents ~50% of our users. And lastly, 'easy to understand' requires not only reducing the sheer amount of content, but also lessening the cognitive effort required by writing the content to be targeted at a fifth to eighth grade reading level.

In the first few months of 2018 , the eGov team and a few other BTS inductees set off to identify our development process and related ’toolchain’, the collection of tools and technologies in support of team development and collaboration. We are now set to begin sprint 27, our 3 week development cycle to deliver continued incremental features and functionality.

Existing tools and applications expected to be impacted by the POWR project effort include:

  • Decommissioning of TrackIt, the City’s in-house developed webform and ticketing system. We are pursuing a suite of cloud-based tools as an overall replacement of TrackIt, including Drupal webforms, Zendesk, SeamlessDocs, and DocuSign depending on the level of sensitivity surrounding the type of information being transmitted to the City.
  • Decommissioning of existing user accounts on the current website, PortlandOregon.gov by moving to a cloud-based CIAM (Customer Identity Access Management) solution in support of an authentication only approach to user identity. User authorization will continue be referred to the respective applications involved for actions allowed within those applications.
  • Migration of existing applications away from the City’s historic ColdFusion platform to that of Drupal or other appropriate technologies. While not specifically in scope by the December 2020 timeline, there are over 70 applications that will need to be retired or migrated away from our ColdFusion platform over time.

We are also proactively working with staff of elected officials, bureaus and offices by holding content workshops whereby we recommend, guide and track their progress of migrating existing and creating new content in support of an overall data-driven user experience, allowing for superior search and relationships between content for end users.

For more information, please check out the City’s beta site, beta.portland.gov and let us know your thoughts at powr@portlandoregon.gov

New Service – Electronic Signatures (eSignatures) – Rick Schulte

BTS will soon be offering a new service to Bureau customers in the form of Electronic Signatures and Workflow. The selected platform is DocuSign which has been configured to manage the City of Portland Organization with Bureaus administrating and supporting their own business processes. DocuSign has also been integrated with Active Directory to provide Single Sign On or SSO authentication.

This new service is designed to make signing documents easy, secure, efficient and fast greatly reducing the time and effort to route and get signatures for City staff and the Citizens of Portland. BES, PBOT, OMF have already been using DocuSign and there is a high demand for this service across the City.

Information on how to obtain this new service will be available at www.portlandoregon.gov/esign

Portland Online Permitting System (POPS) - Kevin York and Saby Waraich

The Portland Online Permitting (POPS) program is modernizing our current permitting system into an online, enhanced customer service delivery system.

Currently, permit technicians input all permit application information into TRACS, a system the City has used to track and manage permits since 1999. This technology supports the development permit process, but it's antiquated and relies heavily on inefficient paper-based transactions.

POPS is comprised of six distinct workstreams, including:

AMANDA

  • AMANDA is the backbone of the city’s permitting system. City of Portland staff use the AMANDA application to track and process permit applications. Upgrading AMANDA is technically a migration of all the data in our old version to the new version (AMANDA 7). The AMANDA Migration upgrades the City’s permitting process from desktop database software that has been in use since 1999 to modern, web-based software. This foundational upgrade retains the functionality of the original database and business processes, providing us a solid base on which we can improve. By upgrading to the newest version, we can continue to expand the current functionality and improve the AMANDA user experience. Our old system is unsupported, and the upgrade will better protect the data.
  • Schedule extended to Q1 2020; project plan being aligned with vendor release plan, adding support, communications, functional readiness and training to plan, to determine optimal timing for rollout that will be least disruptive. Requirements to finalize schedule and rollout still in development.

Development Hub PDX

  • Development Hub PDX (DevHub) is a website developed and maintained by the City of Portland Bureau of Development Services. It provides a quick, easy alternative for contractors and homeowners to purchase simple permits from several bureaus that do not require plan review.
  • Launched Development Hub PDX (DevHub) on July 1, 2019. Officially retired the legacy system Permits Online on August 2, 2019. All activity now routed through DevHub.
  • Postponed DevHub build out in Portland.gov, the new City website design. Will launch in current web platform instead to benefit customer transition to new look/feel.

PDX ePlans

  • PDX ePlans is the Bureau of Development Services’ (BDS) electronic plan review and document management system. Using a web-based tool called ’ProjectDox’, ePlans provides a convenient central hub for development project groups (including applicants and City reviewers) to communicate and complete the entire plan review process online. Staff at BDS and our partner bureaus can review the plans simultaneously on their computer screens. And if customers need to make a correction to their plans, they can submit those corrections online for re-review, saving a trip to the Development Services Center.
  • Co-Sponsor & TOC approved PDX ePlans graduation from the original project scope / Phase I.

Inspection Scheduling

Inspection Scheduling automates the manual process of scheduling daily inspections and assigning them to individual inspectors. Manual scheduling takes time, requires inspectors to come into the office to receive their assignments, and delays the inspectors’ ability to begin their work in the field. Automated Inspection Scheduling using the AMANDA database will increase the effectiveness and efficiency of scheduling and assigning daily commercial, residential, and enforcement inspections.

Benefits of automated Inspection Scheduling include:

  • Optimize the number of inspections that can be assigned in a day
  • Enable inspectors to begin their work earlier in the day
  • Reduce the consumption of paper by routing inspection assignments to the mobile Inspector App
  • Support dynamic updates to inspections and inspector information from the field or office

Inspector App

The inspector App is a new tool that allows resulting inspections in real-time from a mobile device. Our current paper-based inspection forms consume valuable time and slow down inspectors as they work to complete daily assignments. Inspectors will be able to enter inspection results, photos, comments and other items into AMANDA from the field instead of having to wait to transcribe their update when they return to the office. With the app, inspectors can look up information from a mobile device to inform inspection decisions, and along the way, they can use the routing feature in the app to help them plan their stops in the most efficient way. Inspectors can record code violations and accept signatures in real-time while in the field with customers.

Contractor App

The Contractor App enables customers to view their permits, permit details, and the status of inspections online. It also allows customers to receive text messages (SMS) and email notifications regarding the status of their inspections and inspection results. Customers will gain time savings and improved transparency by being able to self-source this information using their mobile devices. While this information will also be available on the Development Hub, this app adds notification in a mobile-friendly way.

Where can I learn more about AMANDA and POPS?

You can find informational videos about AMANDA and the other POPS workstreams on the Bureau of Development Services YouTube channel. Head to youtube.com/BDSOutreach to watch and learn.

Portland Bureau of Transportation Maximo Upgrade – Todd Watson

The BTS Vertical Applications team in conjunction with the PBOT Technology Services team and IBM Maximo Consultants from Banetti are upgrading PBOT’s Maximo 7.1 system to version 7.6 to address Windows Server compliance issues, improve usability, adopt industry best practices for asset management, and incorporate enhancements in alignment with PBOT’s Strategic Plan.

One of the major challenges is that previous deployments of Maximo for PBOT have utilized extensive custom Java class extensions to accommodate multiple customer requests for custom features. Through a combination of process analysis and improvements with the PBOT business systems analysts and our Banetti consultant as well as new system features provided out-of-the-box, we have reduced the number of customized Java class extension files from 195 to 0. This is a major improvement for our overall ability to support, configure, and upgrade the system in the future.

Our current status is that we have build our dev, test and production systems and configured them for UAT of the Maximo user interface to begin the week of October 7th. End-to-end testing, which includes external interfaces to SAP and GIS systems, will occur throughout the month of November. Our currently scheduled go-live date is December 2, 2019.

Corporate GIS Program Update – Matt Freid

Corporate has several major projects going on now and into 2020. We are working with our bureau partners and the System Engineering Team to upgrade all the over 1,000 ArcGIS Desktop clients in the city to the latest version of the software. We are now in beta testing for the newest version of our MapWorks GIS client used to query and view spatial data. The new version will use web services to allow users to access GIS data with just an internet client wherever they are. The team also has lots of projects with bureaus to implement mobile applications, data visualization, and web GIS technology.

Business Solutions Manager Update – Dan Bauer

Additionally, as was announced previously, Dan Bauer is providing oversight of the Business Solutions division during the BSD manager. This will continue during the fall and winter while our bureau focuses on the move back to the Portland Building planned for fall 2019. As we move on to 2020 the next steps for filling that vacancy will be shared across BTS. In the meantime, if you have any ideas for process improvement or how to more efficiently and effectively deliver services in Business Solutions, or any BTS division please let me know. I am always impressed to hear the great ideas that smart and creative BTS employees have to improve our organization.

CONTENT_NAME: Northwest Public Employee Diversity Conference – Sharing Experiences and Lessons Learned
TEXT:
By Ashish Gupta

While walking to office this morning, I was listening to the thoughts of the Indian guru and life coach, Gaur Gopal Das. The essence of his lecture was that it's our generation's responsibility and a failure of humanity if the next generation is not better than the current generation. I was thinking after listening to this lecture that the world needs to practice Equity and not equality to make the world a better place for next generation.  We must ask ourselves what kind of legacy do we want to leave for our children?

The Northwest Public Employee Diversity Conference was held on October 8th, 2019. Thanks to our bureau leadership, we had an opportunity to send 15 staff from BTS. This action demonstrates that Equity and Diversity are a priority to BTS leadership. Below are the experiences/lessons shared by some of the conference attendees. 

Phong Nguyen - Support Center

Overall, it was a good experience. I got to meet people from different agencies and learned some personal and organizational stories. I also learned about how to be an accomplice with your coworkers. Be willing to take action and put your job/career on the line to do what is right. It is challenging for me to take more risks in order to make the workplace a better experience for us all. I have to be the bridge and be able to feel comfortable to discuss all things. But most of all, empathy plays a huge role when dealing with people.

Andy Dhillon - Support Center

I have learned the importance of understanding Microaggressions in a diverse workplace. How small unintentional comments or gestures could impact someone who comes from different backgrounds or cultures. These unintentional impacts sometimes leave a long-lasting impression on a person's thought process and self-confidence. In our efforts to build an equitable workplace, I think it is essential to educate ourselves and everyone around us regarding Microaggressions. We need to be aware, supportive, and, most important, be ready to take necessary steps to ensure that our workplace is safe from physical, verbal, and mental abuse. Sometimes it seems to easy, but I learned from my personal experience that I been using certain words that could be offensive to some people. These work sessions really helped me build a more open and aware mental outlook on these things.

Holly Swan - Support Center

I had the pleasure of attending the Northwest Public Employees Diversity Conference for the third time. I am so grateful to have had the opportunity to attend this event again this year. I always walk away feeling uplifted, encouraged, and challenged in new ways to do better. There were two things that really stuck with me after I left the conference. The first is that it is very important to know your own story, where you come from, and how that relates to the dominant culture of where you are. The second thing I learned was how the power of sharing your story with others and listening to theirs could create empathy and inspire positive change.

Paul Gamboa - Project Management Office

In regards to the event, I was surprised by how late many government organizations are in coming to the table to engage in areas of Diversity. Many folks I engaged with were just beginning to understand the issues, and their departments were just starting committees. Each group indicated that there were tangible concerns in their departments.

Patti Midland - Business Engagement & Strategic Technology

The theme for this year's Diversity conference was "Leading with Racial Equity through Action and Accountability." During the conference, speakers stressed the importance of being leaders in bringing equity into the workplace, regardless of job title, and shared examples of how individuals can make a difference in transforming the culture to embrace Diversity. Though there were many great speakers and a variety of important topics, my personal favorite was Parfait Bassale. Parfait grew up in a non-racialized native West Africa and spoke about his move to the United States. He described the challenges he encountered as he interacted with Americans as a new immigrant as a long journey of self-discovery. Puzzled by the human tendency to zero in on the things that are different in others rather than their similarities, he enrolled in a conflict resolution program in college. In the course of his studies, he researched empathy and realized it was the missing link that, if achieved by opposing sides, could solve all conflicts.  

Parfait explained the "Be the Bridge" model, which is a framework to guide engagement in social justice and equity work:

·        Be Authentic – Allow people to show up as they are. Be you. Respect others.

·        Relationships – People are most likely to form their most intimate relationships with people like themselves. We need to take intentional steps to interact with others that aren't like us and build those relationships to gain perspective from other points of view. Include everyone. Limiting relationships to only people that share our point of view builds an "us vs. them" mentality.

·        Introspect – Examine your thoughts and feelings. We have ownership of how we experience things/people. 

·        Discuss all things – Discuss the uncomfortable. Learning happens when we are the most uncomfortable. Be humble when we hear people tell their stories. Don't minimize what they are saying.

·        Gift your story – Be vulnerable. Sharing your story transforms relationships.

·        Empathy - Communicate from a place of understanding with the intent of moving toward more understanding. Find the counter-perspectives. Empathy is learned, not innate.

The overall message from participants was the importance to be a champion for others. Using our scope of influence, we can create change and remove barriers, make space for others to share their thoughts and perspectives and help them find their voice,  and be the change you want to see. You never know the impact you can have on someone's life.

I hope you find value in this post and share with others in your team. Thank you for taking the time to read the post and supporting Equity and Diversity in BTS.

CONTENT_NAME: BTS Priority Project - September Dashboard
TEXT:
By Ashish Gupta

While working outside on my deck, I had a flashback of earlier days of my career working as a software engineer. I used to wonder how organizations make decisions on which projects to pursue. There are so many opportunities but limited resources. In this blog post, I am sharing a contribution our team makes towards providing information for selecting BTS top projects. 

 

The Business Engagement and Technology Strategy (BETS) team, which includes Technology Business Consultants (TBCs) and Enterprise Architecture (EA), developed a tool and process to capture technology projects coming our way from customers. We call this tool the Technology Planner. Each TBC reaches out to the bureaus/offices in their portfolios to obtain the information about technology needs and initiatives.  We collect information like the business problem, what success looks like, bureau priority, known BTS resources, and chances of moving the project forward. This planner becomes an information source for the selection of top projects at the Technology Executive Steering Committee (TESC). Last year we captured more than 140 potential customers projects for the next 1-5 years. This year we already have 150+ in the list with one more quarter to go. Approximately half of this year’s potential projects were carried forward from last year. The tool and the process is in the early stage of development as we work towards our team focus of being strategic. I will share more in future blog posts as we develop the tool further and refine our process.

 

Below is our September edition of the BTS Priority Project Dashboard. The dashboard has two components, a high-level view of the BTS Project Portfolio, and quick status updates on Programs/Projects prioritized by the TESC.

 

 

The left-hand side of the dashboard provides information on all the active projects, the pending projects (projects with no project manager assigned), and the projects that are scheduled to close in the current quarter. The dashboard is similar to what we shared in August. There are 38 active projects, 14 in the pending queue, and seven projects expected to close by the end of this quarter.

 

The table on the right-hand side of the dashboard provides programs in the TESC's priority order, and the health of the projects under each program. The health indicator follows the standard project indicators of red, yellow, and green. Red means the project is in trouble, yellow means the project in trouble but can get back on track, and green means the project is on track. We added an empty box for projects that are not started yet. The dashboard reflects two projects not yet started, and one of them is scheduled to begin this quarter. The last two columns provide information on whether the project is in progress or starting or ending in the current quarter.

 

We actively seek feedback to get better. If you have attended a Customer Stakeholder Group (CSG) meeting and have feedback, please share it by filling out the survey at https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/CSG-Feedback.

 

Thank you for taking time to read this blog post.

The left-hand side of the dashboard provides information on all the active projects, the pending projects (projects with no project manager assigned), and the projects that are scheduled to close in the current quarter.

CONTENT_NAME: 2019 BTS Customer Survey Results
TEXT:
By Elyse Rosenberg

2019 BTS Customer Survey Results

Each year, BTS surveys Bureau Directors, Bureau Liaisons, Budget Managers, and other key contacts about our services.  The goal of the survey is to gather feedback from key customers about BTS as a provider of technology leadership and vision for the city and BTS as a technology service provider.

This year’s survey was open from May 16, 2019 through June 7, 2019.  We received 99 complete responses from folks in 27 different bureaus.  We’re honored that 99 people cared enough about our service and partnership to spend 10-15 minutes giving us feedback.  Now we need to use that valuable feedback.

Last week, we shared a summary of results and our intended next steps with the BTS Leadership Team and with our Customer Stakeholder Group (CSG).  We also wanted to share a few highlights with BTS as a whole.  You can view the full presentation to the CSG here if you’re interested in more.

 A few highlights:

  • BTS strives to provide technology leadership in support of the City’s business.
       • 42% of respondents think BTS does an extremely effective or very effective job at this from the Citywide perspective.  Another 43% think BTS is somewhat effective at this.
       • 45% of respondents think BTS does an extremely effective or very effective job at this for their Bureau.  Another 44% think BTS is somewhat effective at this.
  • 74% of respondents understand BTS’s priorities and roadmap for technology over the next year. 
  • 92% of respondents agree that “BTS provides value to my bureau” and 83% said they are satisfied overall with BTS’s contribution to their bureau.
  • Customers were asked to tell us about their satisfaction level with 15 services.  On a scale of 1 to 4, these services were rated between a 3.3 and a 2.6. 

Next steps:

  • BTS Leadership and those responsible for services are reviewing detailed feedback and comments.
  • We’ve committed to making improvement plans for services with an average satisfaction rating below 3.0 on a scale of 1 to 4. 
  • We’ll be coming back to our Customer Stakeholder Group later this year with more information about those improvement plans.

While the survey points to several opportunities for improvement, many customers also took time to say how much the value and appreciate the work you do every day.  Thank you!  Your efforts are noticed – keep it up and help us continue to Get Better. 

Please reach out to your Leadership Team member or to me at elyse.rosenberg@portlandoregon.gov or 503-823-6903 if you want to know more.

CONTENT_NAME: Technology Portal & Service Catalog Updates – February 11!
TEXT:
By Elyse Rosenberg

Technology Portal & Service Catalog Updates – February 11!

Did you know that BTS is refreshing our Service Catalog and the Technology Portal?  This effort has been happening since mid-2018 and has involved representatives from every BTS Division.  Our Service Catalog and enhancing the way customers engage with us are key elements of IT Service Management best practice.  And, making it easier for customers to interact with BTS helps all of us spend more time on projects or solving problems rather than directing customers to the right place.  The launch of the updated Service Catalog and soft launch of the updated Technology Portal is happening Monday, February 11!

Here’s part of the new Technology Portal’s home page:

What’s a Service Catalog? 

It’s the way we communicate BTS’s service offerings to our customers. It also drives how tickets are routed.  Currently, we have some services and products described on our website and others programmed in Cherwell (our ticketing system) – and they don’t match.  With this refresh of the Service Catalog, your team representatives worked hard to categorize services in customer-friendly terms and in a way that the services listed in the Technology Portal directly tie to ticket routing in Cherwell.

What’s the Technology Portal and why are we refreshing it? 

The Technology Portal is a tool that customers can use to interact with BTS.  Our goal is to build it into a one-stop resource for technology needs and questions.  We have a portal now, but it’s regularly used by fewer than 500 employees.  We’re refreshing the portal to help customers understand how to access our services and to provide more options for customers to solve their own problems.  One key feature is easy access to a knowledge base of articles customers can use to self-serve.

How will this impact me?

  • The look, feel, and functionality of the Technology Portal is changing, along with the desktop shortcut that takes customers to the portal.  The Cherwell client look, feel, and functionality is NOT changing.  
  • Ticket routing via Cherwell will change to reflect the new catalog.  You will still have all the same tickets assigned to you/your team, but new tickets will come assigned with the new categories in the service catalog.
  • A new Cherwell form was created for tickets associated with applications. Thanks to lots of work with Business Solutions and Public Safety Technology, tickets submitted on this form will be automatically routed to the teams that can help with the application rather than first being triaged by the HelpDesk.
  • If you have built custom processes, custom dashboards, and searches in the Cherwell client that are tied to the Service Catalog, they may break because the catalog is changing.  Most people have dashboards and searches associated with their teams rather than services, so this impact should be limited. 

What’s next?

  • We’ve been doing demos of the Technology Portal for BTS Teams. If you’re interested and we haven’t made it to your team yet, let us know!
  • We’re going live with the updated Service Catalog and a soft launch of the Technology Portal on February 11, 2019.  A soft launch means the Technology Portal will be in production, but we won’t start marketing it broadly until it’s stabilized, and we have initial feedback from those that use it frequently. 
  • Future phases for the Technology Portal will include enhancements to current functions and integrating technology procurement functions.
  • We’ll be exploring ways to add your team to those contributing knowledge articles to the knowledge base – both for your BTS colleagues to troubleshoot issues and for customers to self-serve.  Right now, the knowledge based contains almost 300 articles for customer use and 2000+ for internal use.

Have questions or want a demo?

Contact Elyse Rosenberg (elyse.rosenberg@portlandoregon.gov, 503-823-6903) or Bryan Pirrello (bryan.pirrello@portlandoregon.gov, 503-823-6887)

TEXT:

By Diana Allen

The EBS team supports SAP, the City’s enterprise solution that integrates information for financial, human resources, and procurement business processes.

Our team has been very busy over the past year with a variety of projects, most recently successfully completing our yearly patch cycle.  To close out 2018, we also completed our year end HR updates and numerous changes that need to be in place to support the start of 2019 such as the vacation accrual changes and non-rep study implementation.  Additionally, we partnered with the CBO and supported the interface development to the new budget software BFM, developed the B2G Now interface for payment information and are working with the Bureau of Revenue and Financial Services (BRFS) to schedule their prioritized projects.

In other notable news, Charlie Dudley, our Training and Development Officer, led the implementation effort of uPerform, a documentation tool launched officially in January 2018.  All SAP support documents are being reauthored in the tool. The goal is to completely re-author all SAP support documents into the new format which is then tracked by the system for annual review and updating ensuring all documents are reviewed on a regular schedule.  uPerform can also be used to create online course documents to embed in video lessons linked into the Learning Management System.  Other bureaus are now actively utilizing uPerform for their documentation needs and it has been added to the BTS Standards Directory draft for Fall 2018 as a standard BTS offering. 

On the strategic front - did you know that SAP’s landscape and product roadmap has changed dramatically over the past several years?  With the support of our CTO, Jeff Baer and Deputy CTO, Dan Bauer, we are partnering with our BTS Technology Business Consultants (TBC’s) and our key Bureau stakeholders, to develop a very robust strategic project roadmap to better meet the needs of the City.  Based on feedback, our goal is to improve the user experience, provide improved capabilities, and enhance system performance to improve overall satisfaction with SAP as a Citywide Enterprise Solution.

A key area on the roadmap for Human Resources (HCM) is the migration to SAP’s SuccessFactors (SF).  SF is a cloud-based offering that encompasses Talent Management, Core HR functionality and more robust analytics with an improved modern and intuitive user interface.

Our team, in partnership with the HR Training and Workforce Development team (TWD), implemented SuccessFactors Learning Management System in July which has provided increased flexibility for not only TWD and Citywide training offerings but allows for bureau specific training.  Included are mobile capability, quarterly upgrades, virtual classroom training and a host of other improvements that better meet the needs of the City. This project also set up the SucessFactors platform, which will be used to access future modules.

Currently, the EBS and BHR teams are in the process of implementing the next two modules which are Performance and Goals Management and On-Boarding.  We are extremely excited to partner with BHR to implement these new capabilities.  It fully aligns with and supports the City of Portland’s initiative to be the ‘Employer of Choice’ and the goal to attract, develop and retain a diverse, culturally competent, fully engaged workforce providing excellent public services. 

In the near future, we will be communicating more about our strategic roadmap including the move to HANA databases which will be a key initiative that provides a whole host of improved capabilities.  Below is a subset of the overall benefits/capabilities:

  • Real time information from transactional systems with less reliance on historical and duplicative data stores
  • Improved system performance
  • Modern user experience and responsive design including out of the box mobile capabilities
  • Increased self-service for reporting across the organization
  • Increased automation to reduce manual errors in the reporting process

It’s an exciting time for our team as we see our strategic efforts moving forward.  You know the saying, ‘it takes a village’. Fortunately, we have a ‘village’ of support and help as part of the BTS team. 

We want to close this blog post by saying congratulations to Thang Ngo, a member of the EBS team who won 1st Place in the category of Designer’s Choice at the 2018 Ninth Moon Floral Design Showcase - Lan Su Chinese Gardens.  This event recognizes the floral art and creative talent of the region’s top floral designers.  If you visit BTS at the Columbia Square building – 4th floor, you will see examples of Thang’s creative talents as he provides on-going floral displays for us all to enjoy!

Congratulations Thang!

CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight:  Server Team
TEXT:
By Mike Lamb

What do we do?

The Server Team manages the BTS-supported server infrastructure for the City. We have over 600 servers we manage that are comprised of Windows, Red Hat Linux, and AIX operating systems that run a wide variety of services for the City. Whether you are sending email, drafting a document from a file share, or performing a task in one of the City enterprise systems, the Server Team plays a part in ensuring these systems are running effectively.

We also have a variety of tasks we perform in addition to building servers and addressing Cherwell tickets. We maintain the security compliance on servers, manage enterprise backups, support the emergency paging system, and manage the ROSE domain infrastructure, in addition to many other items.

Who are we?

The Server and Messaging Team is comprised of 12 team members that focus on two main areas: Windows server support and Unix server support.

  • Windows Server Support: Omar Hernandez, Ali Karout (not pictured), David Carter, Mike Nichols, Ryan Ferris, Zane Mullan, Richard Buss, and Patrick Laprocina.
  • Unix Server Support: Patrick Springer, Tom Christian, Dawn Alderman, and Gary Gorski.

Current Projects

Here are some of the projects we are currently involved in:

  • POPS: building servers, assisting the vendors with configuration changes, and ensuring the servers are operating smoothly.
  • Securing the Office 365 Tenant: currently working on configuring and deploying multifactor authentication (MFA) to the City and looking at further steps we can take to secure City data.
  • Data Center Move Phase 2: completing the build out of the secondary datacenter in Colorado.
  • Server 2008 Upgrade: replacing or upgrading all City servers still running Server 2008.
  • AIX Maintenance Windows: establishing AIX maintenance windows so we can establish consistent schedules for updating the servers, installing patches, or upgrading firmware on the hosts.
  • Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) Proof of Concept: working closely with the Systems Engineering Team to configure the VDI test environment to evaluate if the technology is one the City should invest in for the long term.
  • VCAD Upgrade: we are currently working with the VCAD Support Team to upgrade to VCAD 7.5.

Upcoming Projects

We have several projects on the horizon and here are a few examples:

  • Print Infrastructure Management: This project is geared towards developing a print management solution that allows mobile customers to more easily find printers to use, take advantage of printing technologies like “pull printing”, and set up our print infrastructure to adapt to virtual desktops. We will be working closely with P&D as well as the team involved in the move back into the Portland Building to align requirements.
  • Cloud Infrastructure Service Offering: We will be working with a few vendors to review their cloud service offering to see which ones best align with our requirements. The goal is to be able to provide an option for a virtual server in the cloud or on premise to our customers and to understand the cost difference of each one.

CONTENT_NAME: ADA Assistive Technology Standards
TEXT:
By Paul Rothi

In August, BTS completed work with HR to include several ADA assistive technologies in the BTS Standards Directory. Lead by Christian Zenzano, he and Erin Poole from BTS, and Anais Keenon from BHR worked over the summer to identify commonly used assistive technologies. The list was evaluated, and the most common products were recommended for inclusion in the BTS Standards Directory based on conversations with external agencies such as Oregon Commission for the Blind, and an internal look at products already in use within the City’s infrastructure.

This work directly supports several initiatives in the OMF Strategic Plan.

Adopt 21st Century Business Solutions by:

  • Reduce administrative workload on bureaus, with a specific focus on streamlining business processes.
  • Adopt new shared technology platforms.

Develop an inclusive talented workforce by:

  • Support Employer of Choice initiatives to attract, develop and retain the best employees.
  • Strengthen onboarding for City employees.

Prior to this work, most assistive technologies went through the BTS exception process adding time to the onboarding process. Inclusion in the Standards Directory eliminates the need for an exception, standardizes common products, and streamlines getting the product to the employee. The result is a faster time to productivity for the employee!

The entries in the BTS Standards Directory have been identified with a red [ADA] tag throughout the document including the index. There is also an ADA index entry that lists all [ADA] tagged products. A link to the BTS Standards Directory can be found on the BTS Technology Standards web page at https://www.portlandoregon.gov/bts/46940.

CONTENT_NAME: Public Safety IT Division Rolls Out New Hardware for Police Mobile Display Computers
TEXT:
By Chad Lublin

Last year, we were tasked with replacing 376 aging mobile data computers (MDCs) for Police. At a cost of nearly $2 million dollars and with the help of a number of BTS and Police staff, this was no small undertaking. For the past 10 years, Police has used the same devices made by Panasonic. This time around, we decided to review the marketplace to determine whether a better product was available. With advice from local partner agencies, information gathered during an in-house vendor fair, reviews from the BTS hardware standards team and Public Safety Division IT staff, and three rounds of evaluation that included nearly 100 Police users, the team determined that in fact, a better product was available. Enter Getac.

New docking station with a custom Portland Police logo along with correct docking instructions for
the officers.

The new Getac MDCs will be more user friendly, much faster, more ergonomically correct, include a clearer display and integrated ID card reader and driver’s license reader (no more external devices), allow for easier removal from the car, less technically complex, and much easier to troubleshoot.

As of today all new equipment has been procured by BTS Stores, and the Radio Shop has begun deployment and has been trained on support processes. Twenty five police officers and sergeants have been trained to provide in-field support with their contact information provided in every patrol car, five user videos and nine user documents are available as a resource to officers, and a sustainment plan has been agreed upon by the BTS Call Center, Stores, Radio, and Public Safety Divisions; OMF Chief Administrative Office; the Police Chief’s Office and Fiscal Services division; and three vendors.  This includes hardware and software support processes, a life cycle replacement plan, and a financial administration and funding plan.

Pictured left to right:  Scott McCaslin, Adam Coppernoll, and Adam Best.

The project started nearly a year-and-a-half ago and is on schedule and below initial budget estimates by nearly $700,000 (mostly due to negotiations with our vendors). A big thanks to all who have contributed to the success of this project!
