CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight: Customer Relations - A Bridge Between Bureau business Needs and Technology Services
TEXT:
The six members of the Customer Relations Team are responsible for bringing the voice of the customer to BTS.  Our Vision is to serve as “a bridge between Bureau business needs and technology services” and that takes us in a lot of fun and interesting directions.  While you may see our names pop up most frequently when there’s a technology outage to communicate to the City, we do much more than that! 

Who are we?

Team members Chris Cavanagh (currently on loan to the Portland Building Reconstruction Project), Ashish Gupta, Robert Kiningham, Liz Mitchell, Erin Poole, Elyse Rosenberg, and Mark Tanner come from a variety of backgrounds and experience including: IT support, IT management, project management, organizational change management, contracting and finance.  Each Technology Business Consultant (TBC) on the team is assigned to work with specific City Bureaus and Offices.  We develop a primary relationship with a liaison in each bureau, but also work with bureau leadership, management and staff.  Together, we work to understand the business goals of our customers and connect them with technology solutions that help them achieve those goals.  We also work with BTS teams to design new services to meet customer demand and improve our current services. 

How do we do this?  Through Trust and Relationships.  We are committed both to the success of our customers and of BTS.  That can only happen through developing long-term relationships that allow for honest communication, clear expectations, and keeping our own commitments as well as helping BTS keep our collective commitments. 

BTS TBC team, left to right:  Chris Cavanagh, Mark Tanner, Erin Poole, Robert Kiningham, Ashish Gupta, Liz Mitchell, Elyse Rosenberg

Yeah, but what do you actually do? 

Here are a few recent examples of what we do and how we work to move City and BTS business forward…

  • Chris is acting as “TBC to the Portland Building” by bringing together customer needs from the project with technology resources in BTS and via consultants.  Current focus areas include designing common audio/video packages for the Portland Building’s many shared conference spaces and rethinking print management technology to allow for printing to any multi-function device in the building.

  • Ashish facilitates the monthly Customer Stakeholder Group (CSG) meeting as well as BTS’s annual Customer Survey.  The CSG is BTS’ primary customer interaction venue, where we provide timely project and issue information, and solicit customer feedback. 

  • Robert has been working with the City Auditor’s Office on the replacement of software they use to manage processes in the Hearings Office.  This small but important City function hears and makes decisions in Land Use, Code, and Towing Hearings, Appeals of City Decisions, and other administrative matters.  He is providing consistent technology guidance and consulting to the non-technical business process owners, even as both the Hearings Officer and the Auditor’s Liaison responsibilities are transitioning to new people. 

  • Liz is a member of the City’s Smart Cities Steering Committee, along with Jeff and Dan, and she helps coordinate Smart City PDX efforts in BTS. She represented BTS on the sub-group that developed an equity-based Priorities Framework for the City of Portland’s Smart City PDX Initiative that is going to Council on June 13 and is scheduled to include testimony from BTS.

  • Erin has been working with the Bureau of Human Resources and Enterprise Architecture to develop a more streamlined and welcoming way to provide technology accommodations for new employees with disabilities.

  • Elyse worked with the Leadership Team, TBCs, and OMF Business Operations to design a new outreach strategy for BTS’ budget process.  For FY 2018-19, all three of BTS’ budget packages were funded and only one of fifteen cut packages was taken. 

  • Mark has been working with the Bureau of Emergency Communications, the Public Safety Technology Division, and Jeff and Dan to understand requirements and bring in a new medical triage software to integrate with the 911 dispatching process and more quickly get needed help to citizens.  

In addition to many examples like these, we facilitate the BTS Project Intake Process, including coordination with our customers and the BTS resources needed for the projects, we assist customers when they need non-standard hardware or software, we facilitate the review of technology procurements on behalf of customers, we answer all manner of “how do I…” questions, and more!  You can read more about our team’s Vision, Mission, Guiding Principles, and What We Do on our webpage. 

More exciting things coming

If you ask Mark, the most exciting upcoming change is his retirement!  After a long career in public service, Mark will be joining the ranks of the happily retired and moving to a warmer climate.  An open competitive recruitment to fill the resulting vacancy has recently closed and we will be spending time in June, July, and August selecting and onboarding a replacement. 

Elyse and Bryan Pirrello, Support Center Manager, are sponsoring a project to refresh BTS’ approach to IT Service Management (ITSM).  This will involve every BTS team as we work to provide better and more empowered customer access to BTS services through a redesign of our customer portal, a revamp of our Service Catalog, and customer access to our knowledge base.  

Do you have a customer question to work through or an idea for a service improvement in BTS?  Or, do you just want to say hello?  We are located on the 4th floor of Columbia Square in the southeastern corner.  While we’re all frequently out and about at meetings with customers, please stop by or drop any of us a phone call or email!

CONTENT_NAME: Emotional Labor and Women of Color in the Workplace: A Reality Check
TEXT:
Our guest editorial for this edition of the BTS Equity Committee blog was written by Theresa Suico (pronouns of she/her/hers). Theresa has been with the City of Portland for five years, starting her career as an intern in BTS for the Office 365 Project. She then became an Assistant Business Systems Analyst for the Bureau of Development Services. She now works for BDS as a Business Systems Analyst for the POPS Program.

Theresa is Filipino-Canadian and grew up in Micronesia, Canada, and locally, the Oregon Coast. Her diverse background and biculturalism have equipped her with the ability and knowledge to navigate the various spaces she occupies and reconcile her intersecting identities as a young woman of color working in the City of Portland.

Theresa has served on the Hapa, Asian, and Pacific Islander (HAPI) leadership committee, and is currently involved in the Filipino American City Employees (FACE) group as the leadership chair. She is also on BDS Equity Committee as well.

Theresa can be reached at Theresa.Suico@portlandoregon.gov or 503.823.5020. Any interactions with her will require being able to tolerate pictures of her cat, Samwise Gamgee.

By Theresa Suico

The call for organizations to focus on diversity is stronger than ever. Research shows that teams with diverse perspectives produce higher-quality work than more homogenous teams. Even more research shows that companies whose leadership contains a higher proportion of women enjoy higher financial numbers than those with a lower proportion.

All the arrows point to the notion that more diversity in an organization will reap more success. But a question that must be asked is this: What is the reality?

A study performed by Catalyst, a non-profit organization focused on creating inclusive workplaces for women, unpacks this question with a term called "emotional tax", which is defined as "the heightened experience of being different from peers at work because of your gender and/or race/ethnicity and the associated detrimental effects on health, well-being, and the ability to thrive at work."

Given this study on emotional tax, the question being asked must then be refined to: What is the reality for women of color, where this intersection of race and gender meet? (Note: I must preface that I recognize there are so many more intersections of race and gender other than that of a cis woman of color’s, especially intersections experienced by those belonging to the LGBTQIA community. I am focusing on this particular intersection in this article because I identify as a cis woman of color; therefore, this is the only intersection I can speak to from personal experience.)

The implications of the "emotional tax" for women of color in the workplace are staggeringly multi-faceted and dynamic in nature, as women of color are forced to navigate the interplaying forces of race and gender in the workplace, while grappling with instances of microaggressions; being stereotyped; and being tokenized. While these challenges in and of themselves are already heavy to bear, women of color do so while being expected to maintain their current level of job performance; any plans of excelling and pursuing opportunities for advancement require even more work. I interpret this phenomenon to be something called "emotional labor".

"Emotional labor" is a term coined by the sociologist Arlie Hochschild to describe the hidden emotional work service industry workers are expected to perform to positively influence the experience of a customer or colleague. In other words, the service worker must constantly manage their emotions—either by suppressing them, showing them, or redefining them—to achieve the results they want and to get the job done.

While emotional labor often makes its appearance in contemporary culture as something women—and not men—are expected to do in their work and personal lives, I feel it has weightier ramifications for women of color. A common narrative I often hear, and can relate to, when other women of color share their workplace experiences, is that these challenges they face every day, mentioned above—racism, sexism, stereotypes, microaggressions, tokenism, etc.—add to their plate, to the effect that it feels like they have to work two times, three times, ten times as hard as white and/or male counterparts in order to prove that they are competent, knowledgeable, and deserve a seat at the table.

I work as a Business Systems Analyst for the City of Portland. On a personal level, I find my work stimulating and rewarding. But as a young woman of color in the workplace, my job is not without obstacles.

Every day, I perform copious and continuous amounts of emotional labor. I am so accustomed to switching context and tailoring my identity and the language I use to make other people comfortable. I interact with customers and colleagues alike in a premeditated regimen of behavior, designed over the years to elicit a maximally favorable response from those I interact with. If this approach seems a tad too cautious or calculated, trust me—I really would have preferred to walk in the world differently. Whether they are customers, co-workers, or higher-rank colleagues, most interactions for me will require a high degree of internal emotional regulation. As I am constantly performing this emotional labor where everybody is a "customer", there are few people I can be my authentic self with.

I am a young Filipino woman who was not born in the United States. I was the first one in my family to attend an American college. My mother was summa cum laude of her class in the Philippines. My family came here to carve out better lives for ourselves. I felt I needed to do well: to represent my family, make my mother proud, and adjust to this new environment.

Needless to say, I was feeling a little bit of pressure.

As a first-generation immigrant, my reality is that I am not from here. I experience subtle reminders every day that I am not from here, whether it’s the small talk I have a hard time initiating; or my complete lack of familiarity with the area; or the silent question in people’s eyes that asks "what are you?" or "how did you get here?"

I was raised to work hard, yet stay quiet. It is a daily fight to find my own voice amongst others. I am bicultural, having grown up speaking English and having spent my teenage years in Canada. I recognize that this has granted me many advantages that others who arrived here as adults do not have. However, sometimes I feel like the two sides of my identity—the Filipino side, the values I was raised with, and the North American side, the drive to be a leader, to be bolder, to speak louder—are waging war: at the cost of being successful at work, and fitting into this white culture, should I compromise my heritage, authenticity, and identity? Sometimes it is difficult to find that balance. Sometimes, in the workplace, I doubt myself because of this.

Every day, as I collaborate, facilitate, initiate, and all other forms of -ate, I struggle to assimilate into an institution that is predominantly white and is too afraid, too uncomfortable, to talk about race and gender. By ignoring my reality, my workplace is effectively erasing my experience and silencing my voice. At the end of my day, this "hidden" labor, more often than not, manifests in a mental and physical exhaustion.

This tendency to avert the subjects of race and gender is harmful to women of color, as it threatens to blanket our unique experiences under the idea of "meritocracy", a system that serves to advance individuals purely on their ability and effort — the familiar adage of "I don’t see color or gender, I only see ability" may come into mind. This gender and color-invisible stance may have been intended to help under the guise of "equality"—a one-size-fits-all notion—but it is causing more harm than good, especially when played out at the institutional level. By giving everyone the same treatment, and ignoring the nuanced identities of its workforce, an organization is only sabotaging itself and perpetuating a system of inequity. Emotional tax is paid not just by the employees in an organization, but by the organization itself.

I know this is a lot to take in. I know it might feel uncomfortable. But there is a way this can turn around, and at the risk of sounding like a cliché, it starts with you. Be an ally. For me, an ally would be someone who does self-reflection on the way that they walk in the world and how that differs from the way that I walk in the world. They would recognize that these differences may signify that they have privilege in ways that I, as a woman of color, do not. They would listen, get to know me as a person, and recognize that my identity and unique experiences influence my approach to work. They would take the steps to educate themselves without burdening me. They would lean into the discomfort they feel. They would use their privilege to stand up for me and uplift me. Eventually, for my sake, they would feel threads of the same pain that I do. And in them empathizing with and validating my reality, I would feel less of a need to perform emotional labor around them, and be my authentic self more.

Imagine the positive changes that could ripple through a workplace if genuine allyship such as this was practiced at the organizational level—to the extent that women of color feel included, supported, and valued. Imagine the rewards an organization could reap from fostering a work culture that truly embraces diversity and the enriching perspectives that come with it. Imagine if women of color felt like they could be their authentic selves at work, unhindered by the daily task of survival. Imagine instead, if such strength and resilience were unleashed to thrive. This is the kind of organization I would want to work for, and give my all for. This would be the reality that I strive for: a reality that recognizes mine.

* cisgender/cis: term for someone who exclusively identifies as their sex assigned at birth. The term cisgender is not indicative of gender expression, sexual orientation, hormonal makeup, physical anatomy, or how one is perceived in daily life. Source: http://www.transstudent.org/definitions/

CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight - Enterprise Architecture:  Don't Build Your Building Without Plans
TEXT:
By Paul Rothi

Would you build a building without a set of plans showing how the building is supposed to be built? It is through architecture that the building is designed and constructed so the finished product aligns with the business needs and code requirements, and all of the internal systems work and fit together. Architecture plays a similar role in the design and implementation of complex software systems, the planning and coordination of multiple systems across and enterprise, or in planning how the enterprise will respond to technology or business disruptions.

The Architecture is developed in four principle layers – business, information, application and technology – typically in that order. As in the design of a building, the architecture work first identifies what the end result –  the Future State –  is envisioned to look like.

  • Business Architecture focuses on the business outcomes from a business perspective. Business architecture documents how customers, partners and staff interact with the system through the key activities, resources, costs and revenue streams. Capabilities and requirements are then aligned with the desired future business outcomes. 

  • Information Architecture focuses on what information is needed to be successful, who needs it, when and where.

  • Application Architecture examines how the application or system is designed. It also defines how multiple applications work together to deliver the necessary information to those that need it, to fulfill the business outcomes.

  • Finally, Technical Architecture focuses on how the physical infrastructure fits together based on the requirements of the applications, and the City’s established infrastructure.

Information Security and other compliance requirements are considered in every aspect of the architecture work.

Architecture is leveraged to reduce risk. By having a good set of plans, there is a better chance of “building” right the first time. Having a complete picture up front can also facilitate the planning of a series of releases where additional functionality is implemented as a logical progression.

Here are some of the projects and ongoing activities the EA team has recently or is currently engaged in.

  • Continually monitor the Windows 10 and Office 365 feature changes:  The team tracks changes that will likely affect the City’s use of the operating system or Office suite. Depending on the changes, these can be quite disruptive to City operations. As potentially disruptive features and changes are detected, BTS operational areas most likely to be affected are informed so response plans can be formed.

  • POPS Architecture. The Portland Online Permitting System (POPS) is not a single application, but multiple applications within BDS that interface with 10’s of applications both internal and external to the City. The EA team has worked to document and help all bureaus involved understand a business view into the complexity of this undertaking. Below is a diagrammatic tool called a Business Model Canvas that illustrates the complexity of the POPS landscape from a business point of view. Every box within the canvas represents an aspect of the business of permits that must be thought about and addressed by the new POPS system. While not indicated on this version of the canvas, some boxes represent future functionality that will not exist in the initial roll-out. At the technical end, the team is providing high level documentation about the technical architecture which in turn informs where more detailed documentation is needed about systems or interfaces.

(click on image for full size version)

  • Microsoft Licensing and Features: Working with several BTS Divisions, EA dug deeply into the feature and licensing structure of Microsoft’s Windows 10 operating system, Office 365 and a new product offering called Microsoft 365. The purpose was to understand and make recommendations for expanded licensing that aligned with City business needs. This work directly supported the creation of the 2018-19 budget add package for the Enterprise Mobility and Security suite addition to Office 365.

  • Digital / Electronic Signature service design: The team again worked with BTS customers to identify business needs for digital / electronic signatures. The result of the work formed the basis for a 2018-19 budget package to add this service to the BTS portfolio.

  • Portland Building Future Technology: The team is working with the TPB project team and consultants to help insure the building is positioned to leverage 21st century technology when the building is re-occupied sometime in 2020, and flexible enough to accommodate the evolution of technology into the future. This includes technologies in the conference and meeting rooms, building access, printer management, and digital signage. We continually ask questions about the expected technology experience in the building, and work as needed to align and integrate technology platforms to achieve the expectations.

  • Three-month Telework Pilot: The purpose was to engage with BTS’s customers to document experiences teleworking, and make recommendations on how to improve the telework experience. One-hundred two people participated along with 72 managers across 10 bureaus. The results were presented to the Technology Executive Steering Committee (TESC).

  • Assessment and update of the EA service catalog: The team is currently examining the work that we do, the work that we should be doing, and writing a succinct service catalog for EA services. The discipline of EA is continually evolving, and we must evolve our program according to the current trends and City business needs.

The EA team is currently housed on the 3rd floor of Columbia Square. Its members include Paul Rothi, Pablo Chauvin and Christian Zenzano.

CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight - SET: BTS Systems Engineering Team Marks One Year Anniversary
TEXT:
By Lisa Bigley

When the Systems Engineering Team (SET) was formed last year, it was pointed out to me that SET is the name of the Egyptian god of war, chaos and storms. I wondered at the time if that would be an appropriate description for this new team and its inherited responsibilities!

March 6th marked the one-year anniversary of the formation of the SE Team. We celebrated our survival of the year with pizza and took a few minutes to look back on our first year together.

In the beginning

SE Team Vision: Encouraging teamwork, innovation and automation resulting in division-wide process improvement and enhanced customer service. (It’s a lofty vision but the team willingly embraced the challenge).

Goal for the year: Our goal for the year was to successfully transition from our previous teams and form a functioning new team together. We all knew each other and some of us had worked together on other teams, but now we needed to learn how to work together on this new team. And though the systems and processes we are responsible for aren’t new to the city, they were new to most of the people on the team, so we had to work together to cross-train and get up-to-speed as quickly as possible to support our customers.

Who are we?

The team drew its initial members from different technological disciplines across BTS. Each of them brought perspective and experience derived from their work with our other great teams. If you haven’t had a chance to meet them yet, stop by the 1900 building and say hello.

Team Members: James Abudakar, Tony DeFrancesco, Cory Malain, Troy Lambert, Garrett Holyk, Rick Gresham, and Matt Carson

What do we do?

The SE Team manages, maintains and supports the systems that the Support Center uses to do its work, including Altiris, Cherwell, Bomgar, McAfee, AD Manager, OneDrive for Business and Cyberark. We also provide many services for BTS and customers. Here are some of the highlights:

Desktop Security: The SE Team is responsible for city-wide patching and maintains the McAfee Antivirus system. This year, the team researched, planned and implemented a new patching strategy (Power-on-Wednesday) and refined processes around patching and upgrading Windows 10 computers.

Software Deployments & Configurations: We script installations and deploy software for customers who need applications to be installed on a large number of computers. This year, we deployed 19 software packages and updated several others. We also handle GPO Administration for desktop computers and as part of that work, we met with Microsoft and other BTS teams to review the overall health of our group policies. The Group Policy Committee is using the feedback from this session to improve our GPO structure and practices.

Cherwell Design and Management: We manage the Cherwell ticketing system and do design and development work for this system. Some of our recent efforts include: creating a new Appointment module that will be used for customers to schedule phone appointments with the Call Center, design improvements to the knowledge base module, and creating workflows to automated some of our processes.  We also provide consulting services for custom dashboards, reports, and searches. This year we’ll be focusing on redesigning the Customer Portal.

Windows 10 Program: Every 6 months, a new version of Windows 10 emerges and the city needs to review the new release, update the bureau’s application catalogs, visit each Windows 10 bureau to talk with them about testing their critical applications, review the new security baseline, and test and deploy the new OS version and security baseline settings. The team manages this process for each product lifecycle. We upgraded two versions of Windows 10 in the last year.

Altiris Administration: Altiris is used for a lot of the processes in Support Center. Part of the work the SE Team does with this tool (on top of application upgrades, patch management, software delivery, etc) is managing agent health, creating reports, managing software licensing, and providing support for the asset management work done by other teams. This year, the team built a new Altiris server and migrated information from the old server to the new one. Because of this work, we’re seeing improvements in Altiris agent health, which improves our ability to successfully install software and patches on city computers and improves our asset inventory information as well.

What’s next?

The team survived its first year without too many wars, a moderate amount of chaos, and only an occasional storm. During our first annual team meeting earlier this month, we turned our attention to what we can do to maintain and improve our contribution in the coming year. Here are some of items we came up with.

We want to:

  • Be easy to work with and always willing to help
  • Do excellent work and provide reliable solutions that made other’s jobs easier
  • Provide great customer service
  • Complete work for our customers quickly
  • Introduce a new era of automation for the city

This coming year, the SE team hopes to live up to some of these aspirations or at least make progress! We plan to continue our cross-training efforts and endeavor to be better this year than we were last year.

CONTENT_NAME: Brookwood Data Center Set To Expand
TEXT:
By Dave Berg

Many of you can remember the recent project that involved moving our data center out of the Portland Building and into a collocation facility in Hillsboro Oregon. BTS reviewed many different facilities and options when selecting the home of our future data center, and ultimately landed some space in the Brookwood facility owned by ViaWest, which is now called “Flexential”. The newer data center facility was roughly 105,000 square feet of open floor space; dedicated to hosting best in class data center power and cooling for their customers.

As the City moved into the new space, additional customers started to consume floor space as well, including two new submarine cables that would improve network connectivity on the west coast to other countries in the world – Cross Pacific which connects from Hillsboro Oregon to Asia and Hawaiki which connects Hillsboro to New Zealand and Australia.

The Brookwood data center is now going through a construction project to increase its available data center floor space from the original 105,000 square feet to an astonishing 220,000 square feet. To help identify the magnitude of the available data center floor space, the cage that houses the City data center equipment at Brookwood is 540 square feet. The additional space will be added to the North side of the facility, and will include increasing the power capability by an additional 18 Megawatts (MW), and increasing the cooling capacity to support an additional 148,000 square feet. The total power capacity for the entire facility will be 32 MW. That may not be enough power to send Doc and Marty into the future, but 32 MW is enough to power an estimated 32,000 homes! Once the new facility is constructed and ready for production use, access will be made between the older facility and new facility between the current exterior North wall. Flexential estimates the construction to be completed by August at the latest.

The demand for data center floor space within the Brookwood facility will increase the availability of resources such as network connectivity options, power and cooling redundancies, and backup power capabilities. The growth is exciting for our region, and shows the continued shift in IT to move away from data center facility management, and put the onus back on the companies that make it their business to provide these state of the art, reliable services.

CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight - eGov:  PDX Reporter Featured on KATU News at 6
TEXT:
By Greg Clapp

Portland television station KATU recently visited BTS to talk on camera about the new PDX Reporter web app and learn about the upcoming version 1.0 release. The segment was featured on KATU News at 6, on January 16, 2018. 

PDX Reporter: City's web app for reporting neighborhood problems to get an upgrade

During the interview, I chatted with KATU News reporter Stuart Tomlinson chatted about the history of the app, the upcoming release, and some of the more popular report types submitted by Portland residents. Tomlinson, a fan and frequent user of the app, commented off camera that he and his neighbors have had great success getting issues resolved through its use, and he wanted to bring more awareness of it to the public.

Originally launched in 2009 as a native iOS and Android app, the PDX Reporter web app beta version was publicly released in April, 2017. The web app was developed by myself and Brittany Smart, and we continue to support and extend it. 

“It's a universal version that can basically be used on any device with a web browser phone, desktop, tablet,” [Clapp] said. “It gives us a lot more flexibility for creating, updating and doing bug fixes, adding new features."

“It's going to be dramatically improved over the beta -- we've learned a lot of lessons over the last eight months,” said Gregg [sic] Clapp of Portland’s Bureau of Technology Services. 

The improved Version 1.0 is expected to hit in late February or early March, 2018. The initial beta was a hastily made prototype designed to mimic the functionality of the aging native phone apps and allow those apps to be retired. Completely rewritten as a true HTML5/AngularJS single page application, the new 1.0 version will boast new features, a more usable interface, and the ability to support customized reporting forms.

CONTENT_NAME: Taking Photographs for Time Lapse of Portland Building Construction
TEXT:
By Paul Cone and Paul Hill

Paul Hill with BTS Communications purchased a pair of Nikon D3300's (low end DSLRs) and also a couple of intervalometers.  Both of those are designed to run on battery so he rigged up some battery replacers connected to AC adapters.  He also found couple of uninterruptible power supplies to plug it all into.  We put a 64 GB card in each and set the intervalometers to take one picture per hour.  We set them up on the 11th floor of the Justice Center (BTS at PPB) and the 6th floor of the Congress Center (PBOT).

The one at Congress took some work to minimize the reflections – the double-pane glass with the wide angle is the culprit.  Mostly this involved taping up some black paper and also cannibalizing an empty black 11 x 17 binder we found. 

They are taking a picture once an hour.  The SD cards are big enough take both a JPEG and a RAW image at the same time, for about 1300 shots, or about 56 days worth. We will plan on coming back once a month or so for the next three years to swap out the SD cards. 

We're not sure what the end products will look like but we're thinking both a series of still as well as videos could be derived from the photos.  If you have any experience creating time lapse movies from still images, let us know.

CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight -  Information Security:  Secrets of the Inner Sanctum Revealed
TEXT:
By Christopher Paidhrin

A question Information Security team members get fairly often is, “What do you do?”

Our team is tucked away behind a locked door labeled “Inner Sanctum” on the third floor of Columbia Square. This is a name we did not choose for ourselves. Our preference would be to work in a shared security operations center, where Network Team, Server Team, Support teams and all operational security staff could share a common workspace. Instead, out of necessity, we toil away in an intense and fervent atmosphere, out of sight. What we do isn’t much talked about because a fair portion of it is rightly confidential.

Pictured above:  Not the real City of Portland InfoSec team.

While each team member has assigned scopes of work—and workbooks of tasks, outside of Cherwell tickets—there is a fair amount of cross-training and support. Our focus is on our core service catalog, which distills into a small number of security-related services: Governance, which includes strategy, planning, policies, contracts, compliance and regulations; Security Architecture and Design, which includes standards, exceptions to Admin Rules, new technologies and projects; Risk Assessments, which help bureaus identify and remediate challenges in their workflows and environments; Incident Response, which includes forensics and analysis of a spectrum of detected threats and attacks; Awareness and Education, which includes CityLearner modules, Just In Time individual training, and bureau focused education sessions; and Monitoring and Alerting, which includes a collection of tools that watch for bad things happening across the City’s diverse technology environments.

In addition to the ongoing scope of activities, the Information Security team is excited to engage many BTS and Citywide teams with our roster of security projects:

  • GRC (Governance, Risk, and Compliance) Cherwell workflow module: Kick-off is this February with Support Center and Cherwell, with the goal to automate the City’s compliance workflow. Think of all that the City does for PCI Compliance and imagine that a quarter of the work effort can be automated. The City has six compliance regimes, but we don’t have six teams. The goal is to layer on, de-duplicate, and automate all compliance efforts to minimize the burden on everyone’s time and effort.
  • Firewall Technology Refresh: The Network Team and Information Security are aligning to revision the City’s core security model and platform. A lot has changed in the years since our last technology refresh. The diversity and scope of City services and requirements call for an evolution in security architecture. These are exciting times!
  • Identity Security Initiatives: Information Security is partnering with peer BTS teams to explore two-factor authentication, privileged access management, and related capabilities for remote and mobile access to City technology resources.

The City is abuzz with change, and each change of policy, technology contract, exception request, and security incident, all require some degree of attention from our team. Behind the Inner Sanctum door, there’s a lot going on.

CONTENT_NAME: Thank You City of Portland from Free Geek
TEXT:
The City of Portland has had a symbiotic relationship with Free Geek for over a decade.

Free Geek’s mission is to sustainably reuse technology, enable digital access, and provide education to create a community that empowers people to realize their potential.  This fits easily into the City’s overall sustainability, recycling and community development goals and desires.  Over the course of the last decade plus, the City has provided Free Geek with thousands of computers which have been used to educate citizens and provide technology to community organizations, schools, non-profits and individuals.

Free Geek's Hardware Grants program provides computer hardware to nonprofit organizations that are in need of new or upgraded technology and do not have the resources to acquire that technology. The incoming stream of used City of Portland computers allowed them to fill grant requests from Portland nonprofit organizations. Hardware Grants to organizations such as VOZ Worker’s Rights, Community Cycling Center, Write Around Portland, Sierra Club, Saturday Academy, Charles Jordan Community Center, Artists Repertory Theatre, Mercy Corps NW, and the Urban League of Portland, just to name just a few.

In 2010, Free Geek's program Plug Into Portland was created to specifically target students in the Portland Public School system and provide refurbished computer systems to any K12 student that had completed 24 hours of volunteer service in their communities. Over the years the program has gained recognition as they reach out to various schools, parents, and administrators.  During one six-month reporting period, students volunteered over 1,440 hours of time in their community.  Free Geek approved 60 applications and disbursed computers to those students serving their community. With each computer they gave away they had each student/family attended a digital literacy class where they taught them how to use the systems effectively.

In addition to providing a conduit for refurbishing computers and supporting community based organizations in the Portland Metropolitan area; Free Geek performs the, underappreciated, service of providing a sustainable and environmentally friendly recycling resource for the City’s old, broken and reusable Electronic equipment and media.

CONTENT_NAME: BTS Team Highlights – Corporate GIS
TEXT:
By Matt Freid

The mission of our team is help customers put the ‘Where’ in their data and applications.  GIS stands for Geographic Information Systems and at its core is a technology that allows you to find spatial relationships between otherwise unrelated datasets and create applications that utilize location.   When you use Google maps or the GPS in your car you are tapping into the power of GIS and we work to make this type of functionality available across our enterprise.

Our program has been around for almost 20 years now but we still do our best to add new tools that developers and customers can use to meet emerging needs.   Along with supporting over 1200 GIS desktops installs and publishing 1500 datasets provided by almost every city bureau we have been building out our web based systems to increase access for more employees and citizens.  We work with GIS staff in the bureaus, the Vertical Applications team and rely on Production Services, Networking, Communications and many other groups in BTS to make these projects successful.  Here are a few ways that we have been employing web GIS with our existing systems over the last year.

Snow Plow Locations and Real Time Data – One of the most interesting and challenging projects we have been involved in this year is a collaboration with PBOT and Vertical Applications to produce a public facing web map showing the locations of snow removal vehicles in real time.  Remember the challenges of getting around the city last winter in all the snow and ice?   Out of that experience came a desire to show what the city was doing to respond not after the fact but during the event to help citizens see where work was being done in as close to real time as possible.  This challenge helped us create a GIS implementation utilizing data from Internet of Things devices in a transportation project, demonstrating how the BTS can get involved in efforts like Smart Cities and supporting autonomous vehicles.

The first step was getting data from the vehicles.  Michael McDonald with Vertical Applications worked with the vendor that provides the GPS units in all PBOT trucks to create a process that constantly queries a data endpoint to get location and operational data once a minute.  This data is then made available through a web socket that our systems can pick up.   Working with PBOT staff, Mike Quetel, Ryan Chen and Kellie Hauger on our team added a new piece of GIS software called GeoEvent Server that consumes data from this source and provides it to a web page that refreshes as the data changes, showing the snow plows moving around as they clear the streets.  There were many challenges in automating and visualizing this data in the way that the customer wanted it to be communicated, but the product is ready for use on your desktop or mobile device before the first snowflakes of the season fall.  Look for PBOT to promote it to the public the next time there is a threat of winter weather.  Update 11/16/17 -- the plow map is now live, here.

Fiber Route Mapping – Sometimes we get the opportunity to get involved in a project where BTS itself is customer.  One example is setting up a web application that allows BTS staff to GIS edit data in the field, making it easier for subject matter experts collect data and share easily share it.   The Fire Bureau and BTS Communications were looking for a way to create a map showing where an existing coax cable system is located and use it to see where future infrastructure could be placed once it is retired over the next few years.  Previously field notes were translated into a digital version back in the office which made the process slower and potentially less accurate.  CGIS team members Paul Cone, Kellie Hauger and Mitch Vanderperren created an editable web mapping service on our infrastructure that can be updated on an iPad using just a web browser.  This data is also shared out to other agencies like Tri-Met directly so they can see changes instantly and then work with the city to design fiber routes to reach new customers and improve network performance for city staff.  In the future in could be incorporated into projects like the one CGIS team member Tammy Dong has been working on with the Communications Division to plan how the city’s fiber program can grow over time.

You can see the interactive map at http://pdx.maps.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?webmap=9d72004f356147fdb7e8aafd70e7faf1

ArcGIS for Enterprise – One of the newest web GIS platforms we have been working with is ArcGIS for Enterprise, which has promise to offer some interesting new use cases for browser based mapping applications in the City.  The previous examples use the ArcGIS Online platform to create web maps and applications – it is the cloud based content management system provided by our main GIS software vendor ESRI.  ArcGIS Online is great for sharing content with the public and works well with data on our servers, hosted data as well as web mapping services shared by other agencies while ArcGIS for Enterprise is an on-premise version of this same system that adds additional functionality.  A key use case it provides is sharing content easily with people in our organization only – on ArcGIS IOnline this requires managing an identity to distinguish a subset of city staff from the public.  CGIS team members Aaron Kilbey and Trevor Smith have been working with Production Services to integrate ArcGIS for Enterprise into the city network, allow supporting sharing of internal content like engineering schematics or workgroups collaborating on draft applications before they widely published.   Since ArcGIS for Enterprise utilizes a web architecture, users can also access content on mobile devices much like they do with Office 365, making it easy to use these applications anytime from anywhere.

We are excited about the new ways that GIS is being used by BTS and the bureaus.   If you are interested in learning more about how to use GIS and apply it to what you do, please let us know.

CONTENT_NAME: New Phone System for 911 Calls Goes Live at BOEC
TEXT:
By Paul Cone

In Portland and Multnomah County, Bureau of Emergency Communications (BOEC) is the conduit through which most emergency service-request information flows. 

A new phone system went live starting at 12:01 this past Tuesday at BOEC.  Working alongside teams from Airbus (yes, the same company that makes jets also makes systems for 9-1-1 centers) and CenturyLink, staff from BOEC and BTS worked to set up both the new hardware and software for the new VESTA 9-1-1 system.  VESTA brings a host of new technology to the BOEC call floor:

  • Approximately $2.5M of State 9-1-1 funding is being allocated to the upgrade.
  • This upgrade requires collaboration between Airbus, ECATs, CenturyLink, and Goserco, along with the Bureau of Emergency Communications (BOEC) and the Bureau of Technology Services (BTS).  
  • New Vesta 9-1-1 VOIP emergency phone system with Automatic Call Distribution (ACD) functionality.
  • Replacing 50 Vesta call taking/dispatch work stations to move from Windows XP to Windows 10.
  • Replace 100 monitors and 50 specialized keypads.
  • Installing 8 new network switches.
  • New servers to support Vesta 911, mapping and analytics.
  • Vesta mapping to plot call locations on a dedicated interactive map.
  • Cell Call Filter feature so all call-flow time stamps will be documented in the statistical database.
  • Analytics database -- statistical analysis based on 9-1-1 call data and time stamps.

Maureen Kinzel-Grubbs spent many long hours and months coordinating this effort.

Thai Nguyen also did a lot of work to deploy the new hardware on the dispatch floor, including taking the opportunity to clean up the hundreds (thousands?) of cables used.

Suzanne Hannam and I worked on building the data and setting it up to be used on the twin dedicated servers running ArcGIS Server.

Below are some photos of the project.

CONTENT_NAME: SAMS - Sexual Assault Management System
TEXT:
By Ed Arib and Cloy Swartzendruber

Figure 1: Patricia Barrera, Molly Daul, Susan Lehman, and Ed Arib at SAKI conference in Washington DC

SAMS is a web application developed by the Portland Police Bureau ITD division for the sex crimes unit. Its purpose is to track every aspect of the sexual assault kit from collection to property room storage, forensic lab testing, and DNA results from the FBI CODIS system (Combined DNA Index System).  The goal is to identify offenders and provide the information needed for prosecution.  SAMS also tracks detailed information about the police case, suspect, victim, trafficker and different type of evidence.  It is also used by Portland Police embedded victim advocates to document all their interaction with sex crime victims. SAMS is also used to fulfill the reporting requirements for the SAKI (Sexual Assault Kit Initiative) grant and the DANY (District Attorney of New York) grant.

SAMS was presented at the following national conferences: SAKI National Meeting in Washington, DC, and Detroit SAK Summit in Detroit, MI and was recognized as the first application available dedicated to tracking sexual assault cases and the collection and testing of sexual assault kits.  Portland Police decided to share this application with any Police Department at no cost.

The success of SAMS generated a lot of interest from a number of police departments nationwide that don’t have any complete solution for managing sexual assault kits.  In order to continue developing and enhancing SAMS with more advanced features that would not only help the Portland Police Bureau but could also benefit a large number of police departments nationally, PPB applied for and obtained a one million dollar federal grant.  This new grant will be used to enhance SAMS by adding bar code tracking, kit testing prioritization, advanced search functionality, business intelligence, and a mobile application for SANE (Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner) nurses to use for their forensic exam.

On October 2nd through 4th, the City of Portland’s Police Bureau held the annual Summit of Cities SAKI conference at the Portland Convention Center.  This conference was organized by Molly Daul and Susan Lehman of the Portland Police Bureau. Portland was chosen as the site for the 2017 conference because of our work on SAMS (Sexual Assault Management System).

You can see the photo below, the kick-off of the conference with the Police Honor Guard, along with Mayor Ted Wheeler, Police Chief Danielle Outlaw, Multnomah County District Attorney Rod Underhill, and Commander Dave Hendrie.

Figure 2: Police Honor Guard, Mayor Wheeler, Police Chief Outlaw, Multnomah County District Attorney Underhill, and Commander Hendrie at SAMS conference in Portland

Additionally, Ed Arib (seen in the photo below) and Susan Lehman presented the latest version of the SAMS system at the conference. Ed and Susan have been the brains behind the creation of this system. SAMS is being used in multiple jurisdictions across the country to manage sexual assault kits.

Figure 3: Ed Arib presenting at SAMS conference in Portland

There were 185 attendees from across the country and 48 breakout sessions took place at the 2 ½ day conference here in Portland. The conference included law enforcement, prosecutors, advocates and nurses.

CONTENT_NAME: Spotlight - Network and Telecom
TEXT:
By Dave Berg

BTS Team Highlights – Network and Telecom

I’m sure all the BTS family can agree that the last few months have been extremely busy. The time is flying by. It feels like yesterday was June and tomorrow will be January. I’ve submitted an RFP for a pause button, but I’m not sure it will come through in time. ☺

Over the last couple of months, the Network and Telecom team have focused primarily on the Data Center Move, Portland Building renovation and move out, VoIP deployment, and DWDM installation, all while maintaining our current environment, combating phishing, other cyber security issues, and supporting our customer’s operational needs. It’s been stressful, but the team has kept their spirits high and have accomplished a mountain of work while also building trust within the team.

 

Here are a few recent highlights for the team:

Data Center Move – Jeremy Boyd has done an outstanding job with designing and building a resilient network with a 40 Gig backbone that connects systems and services together in our new colocation space. This has not been an easy task, but Jeremy continues to drive the project forward. The new data center network fabric is installed and connected between Brookwood, Comm Center and TPB. Thanks to the work of Rebecca Huston, Jeff Yentz, Matt Cowan, and Kirksey Neumeyer, DWDM has been deployed to support multiple channels dedicated to the data center traffic. The 10 Gig ring is up and functional at Brookwood, and we even moved our SSL VPN appliances and one of the firewall clusters to Brookwood!

For those who have not been to the new colocation facility, here is a great virtual tour video:

https://www.viawest.com/knowledge-center/videos/viawest-brookwood-data-center-virtual-tour

 

Avaya VoIP migrations – The drive for the City to retire the old, analog infrastructure continues. The Telecom team has done an amazing job with these VoIP migrations! Over the last 9 months, the Telecom team has replaced around 1,450 phones within the City, which brings our total Avaya user count to around 1,950 total users. The goal is to restart the migrations after the TPB moves are complete. The result will be a new Avaya version 7 platform and a total of around 5,000 users by early 2018. One of the highlights for the Avaya version 7 design includes system redundancy between facilities.

 

 

TPB Renovation and temp office spaces – Matt Cavaness has done an excellent job designing and connecting the three new temporary office locations that support the City employees. Kirksey Neumeyer has been focusing on building out each of the new office spaces for network connectivity (see the beautiful cabling job by Kirksey in the image below). At this point, we have completed four weekends of moves, which include: installing 27 switches and 43 wireless access points, moving 504 VoIP phones and 28 printers. Just under 500 people have moved out of TPB and into Columbia Square and 400 SW 6th.

 

 

Fiber support – Rob Durkin manages our outside plant and fiber infrastructure. Recently, we had an issue where a leg of our 10 Gig ring and DWDM fiber was burnt, which required immediate repair. Rob partnered with Rebecca Huston on the 10 Gig ring side to restore the service. We dispatched one of our fiber repair companies on short notice, and they worked from around 6:00 PM until after 1:00 AM to restore service. It was a long night, but we are glad to have our fiber back! Below is an image of the work starting.

 

Wireless growth – In July and August, Janelle Bentley and Pavel Probasco processed 385 wireless devices and resolved over 500 Cherwell tickets! It is amazing how the wireless world of cell phones and tablets continues to grow within the City. The announcement recently came out from Apple about the new iOS 11 and Apple suite of devices. The MTRC will be reviewing these new devices and iOS features in the coming weeks, and they will determine which devices we will adopt for our standards, and when we should upgrade to the new iOS version. 

iPhone X

BTS Employees,

Moving Day - It’s hard to believe that in less than a month (August 18th!) we will be the first bureau moving out of the Portland Building to our temporary location. Being the first ones out means we get to pave the way for the other bureaus as they start to migrate out of TPB and into their temporary locations. This will be a significant organizational and cultural change in how we interact with other city employees and bureaus and will take some time to adjust to our new surroundings. The physical environment has been built out and some non-production applications are already migrated. The migration schedule has been published and over the next several months everything will be moved out to the Brookwood site.

Public Safety Technology Division - We launched the new Public Safety Technology Division on July 1. Much work has been going on over the past month to ensure a smooth launch. The technology support personnel for Portland Fire and Rescue, Portland Police Bureau, Portland Bureau of Emergency Management and the Bureau of Emergency Communication are now under a single unified public safety technology division. 

An important next step is to convene a Public Safety Steering Committee to discuss the overall governance and focus for this new Division. I’m really looking forward to identifying where we can take advantage of opportunities to strategically align technology support resources within this new structure. Last week we held a division meeting and I want to thank those who could be there for their participation in the discussions. Excellent information we received regarding change management and the impact it has on those involved in the reorganization.

SoT – We just received the results of the Speed of Trust Survey and are starting to work our way through all the information received. I’m hoping this is a good indicator that we are making progress in this effort and I want to thank those who took the time to respond and provide your comments to help us create a culture of trust within our bureau. As always, I’m happy to answer any questions.

Jeff

CONTENT_NAME: OMF Sponsoring Teleworking Pilot Project
TEXT:
By Pablo Chauvin and Dan Bauer

As you may be aware at the recommendation of the BTS Labor Management Committee our bureau has been leveraging flexible schedules and telework as ways to provide increased work-life balance, and more recently to accommodate working condition changes arising from the Portland Building Reconstruction Project.  These alternatives are not one size fits all solutions, but the expanded use of these tools will allow us to use them even more effectively. 

For more information and policies regarding BTS flexible schedules and telework please refer to Bureau Policies. 

Initial BTS efforts with regards to the technology of implementing teleworking have focused on piloting flexible schedules and expanded telework and gathering feedback from staff experiences.  So far feedback has been very positive. Due to that success BTS is now partnering with OMF to expand a teleworking pilot outside of BTS.  

Project Background

OMF developed a telework pilot to evaluate how we can expand teleworking options for staff. The pilot has been discussed in the context of the Portland Building Reconstruction Project, but the intent is to leverage whatever we learn across bureaus, particularly because learning how to effectively and responsibly implement telework policies will be a critical piece in the City’s effort to become an “Employer of Choice,” especially with the demographic shifts in our workforce over the next few years.

In addition to our long-term interest in telework, given the recent snow and ice events there is a desire to look at teleworking as a continuity of operations tool for some employees in cases of office closures. This pilot project gives us the opportunity to evaluate how work may be appropriately accomplished in a telework environment and will help inform us how we can successfully move the City towards more flexibility in how we work.

(click on the image to download a PDF)

Project Status and Next Steps

There are roughly 100 participants spread across ten bureaus participating in the pilot, which kicked off in March and is scheduled to last 3 months, wrapping up towards the end of June.  Although this pilot is short in duration, bureaus are encouraged to continue to pilot teleworking within their respective bureaus. 

BTS has provided project updates to the Customer Stakeholder Group  and the OMF Business Hour group earlier this month and management seems to have a positive and optimistic view of teleworking.

The first of three surveys is scheduled to go out to pilot participants the week of April 24th.

If you have any questions on the pilot projects please contact Pablo Chauvin or Dan Bauer.

CONTENT_NAME: Walter’s Hill Radio Site Upgrade Project
TEXT:
By Bob Ochs

History

After the initial 800 MHZ radio was first deployed in 1992-3, there were major radio coverage problems in Gresham metro area.  After a lot of research, the solution was to install a 5 channel site on Walter’s Hill. The site had very limited room, but provided the necessary coverage. It was supposed to be a temporary fix, which of course became permanent.

So finally in 2010, Scott Howes and I began the planning for the new site. We priced out a 140’ tower with communication buildings at the base; the CIP budget was $600K. We started to have neighborhood meetings and saw that it was going to get complicated very quickly which of course it did. We redesigned the site plan by changing the building to look like a home to be more conducive to the neighborhood. This defused the objection of decreased property values. After 2.5 years of many meetings and revisions, we submitted a design that included a 2,400 sf building and a 70’ tower. The land-use application was approved by City of Gresham, but then the Walter’s Hill neighborhood association filed an appeal. After five months of planning, attorneys and a hearing, the appeal was denied. Due to the many changes and revisions, the cost of the project went from $600k to $1.13 million.

Construction

We started construction in early 2016 with the low bidder, 2KG Constructors, Inc.  Construction continued for all of 2016 and into 2017. The job was delayed by many unforeseen problems, here are some of the main issues we addressed:

1. We found an old cistern right where the tower foundation was designed to go.

2. The heavy spring rains delayed the site excavation. The contractor even sunk a D8 excavator in the mud. See pic.

3. We found the untouched dirt behind the old house was unsuited for supporting any sizable weight load. We replace 20 truckloads mud for 20 loads of 4” minus rock to stabilize the area.

4. The soils under half of the poured slab had to be removed and replaced for the same reason (as #3).

5. We had to remove over 700 lbs. of trash dumped in a ravine just south of the old house. 

6. The new sprinkler system design was not familiar to the install company.

7. The surplus generator we planned to use had to be replace with a “UL” listed model, which changed the entire air ventilation and exhaust parameters.

Current status

  • We are finalizing the new generator install.
  • The site is currently connected via “T1’s”, a microwave path to Prune Hill is proceeding.
  • The fire system permit and the final building permit is in process.
  • Once we receive from the contractor the final liability release, retainage release, warrantee and maintenance bonds received, and final payment docs, we will close the project
  • Lessons learned will be the final step on the project.

CONTENT_NAME: Speed of Trust at the All Hands Meeting
TEXT:
By Brian Ventura

The FranklinCovey Speed of Trust program and training continue to make a difference for BTS. We adopted Speed of Trust in February of 2016 and now have completed training BTS staff and management. I am encouraged by the changes I witnessed over the last nine months.

In November, BTS held an All Hands meeting and it was a great success. I specifically want to highlight the talk regarding Speed of Trust and the difference it made for Boyd Coffee. Jeff Newman, President and CEO, and Ann Nordquist, VP of HR, from Boyd Coffee attended and spoke at our All Hands regarding their adoption of the Speed of Trust in 2010. Jeff and Ann explained they have seen drastic, positive changes in the past six years. That encourages me regarding the impact we can achieve in BTS and the City as a whole.

Boyd Coffee is a Portland union shop, as we are, so the Labor Management Committee was very interested in how Speed of Trust affected their environment. Boyd explained their culture was significantly divided between the office workers and the staff workers. For them, they had informal terms of “the carpet people” and “the concrete people”, referring derisively to the office management/staff and production floor staff respectively. Production workers thought management did not trust them and did not care about them. Management wanted to change this and recognized they could be put out of business due to the significant market changes and lack of coherence between employees and management.

Jeff and Ann adopted the Speed of Trust, with the goal of spreading trust throughout the organization. Jeff explained they started with him and the Management staff to adopt the language and transparency of the system, then brought it to the Union staff. Boyd’s successes were great.

The story that stood out the most for me was around their need to streamline production. Jeff explained, the experts told them they needed a large piece of equipment that cost too much for their size and budget. They did not know what they could do to stay competitive. So through the Speed of Trust, they went to their production staff and presented the problem, explained the inability to purchase expensive machines and the concern Boyd would lose market share without a solution.

The production staff were surprised. They did not know how the business was run, they did not know what the market was like, and they did not know what Boyd wanted to do outside of their day-to-day jobs. The production staff came together, worked with Management and designed an innovative, lower cost solution to drastically increase production, while spending a fraction of the proposed new equipment cost. Now Management continues to engage the staff and give transparent insight into the company’s working and goals.

On the union contract front, Jeff explained, they began, and continue, to complete their contract negotiations in a fraction of the time, before the contracts end, and with both Management and Union happy with the outcomes.

If you did not get a chance to participate directly in the All Hands and witness this yourself, then you can go to the Speed of Trust website (http://www.speedoftrust.com/boyds_coffee) to watch Jeff and Bob Stanley, their Union representative, talk about the impacts! The video links are toward the bottom of that posting. I encourage each of us to watch those videos as they are inspirational and a hint at what we can achieve with the Speed of Trust in BTS!

By the way, we asked them how the negative terms, Carpet People and Concrete People, were handled and they said they embraced the terms and made them into positive examples of what they can accomplish with Trust. To show trust and building an inclusive environment, they purchased remnant carpet pieces to put on the production floor and they took out the carpet in the entry lobby to show they were a company built on a foundation of concrete. They even told a small story about one of their longest standing employees, who was previously disenfranchised. He had previously stated he would NEVER walk on the carpet side, his distrust was that high. One day, a year after the Speed of Trust was embraced, he went to Jeff’s office and said, “you say you have an open door policy, is it true or just talk?” Jeff answered that it was a true open door policy and they had an open and honest conversation, the first conversation they ever had in the many years they worked together.
