CONTENT_NAME: Drone Applications in a Municipal Environment
TEXT:
By Jeff Baer

Drones or Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) have been widely used in the hobbyists and military markets. Recently the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) released new rules that went into effect August 29, 2016 around civilian drone usage. These changes will open the door for many new commercial applications, but it’s also good to know that these rules are designed to minimize risks to other aircraft, people and property on the ground.

“People are captivated by the limitless possibilities unmanned aircraft offer, and they are already creating business opportunities in this exciting new field,” said Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx. “These new rules are our latest step toward transforming aviation and society with this technology in very profound ways.”

As the commercial market matures you will see more drones used in a variety of settings. As an example, we’ve recently been working with a local drone company to determine if they could be used to provide aerial inspections of our public safety radio towers using their high definition filming capabilities. These drones have interchangeable camera and sensor capabilities, so we are interested in seeing how they could be used to visually inspect these towers.

You can start imagining how drones could be used in a variety of other visual inspections, such as providing eyes in the sky during certain events like traffic accident investigations, assessing a scene of a disaster, search and rescue operations and other law enforcement activities. You may even see drones tethered to police and fire vehicles and deployed during certain events. 

There are many possibilities that this new and emerging market creates, but it will have to be carefully thought out as there are many safety challenges associated with their use. The FAA established the Unmanned Aircraft Safety Team to gather and analyze data to enhance safety and operations of drones in the nation’s airspace.

Overall it will be exciting to see the variety of new ways and new markets that drones will be used in the coming years. Stay tuned.

CONTENT_NAME: Why Am I Getting A Smaller Computer?
TEXT:
By Aaron Liljenberg, BTS Outer Support Lead

The Bureau of Technology Services Support Center Hardware Standards Panel was established last decade with the unique vision to research and recommend stable and cost effective client computing platforms and peripherals which meet the business needs of the City of Portland.  The success of the Hardware Standards Panel is based on the facilitation of open and inclusive dialogue among support teams and customer bureau employees.  As needed, the Panel is tasked with evaluating the various requests for specific computing hardware that bureau employees may require.  The Panel works with the customer to establish the business need and establish the case for approving the request or determining an alternate solution that could better suit the need.

The panel also evaluates and recommends standard computing hardware models and platforms in order to provide excellent and timely service in deploying the equipment that City employees use every day.  Thanks to the development and stocking of standard equipment BTS support teams are able to quickly configure and deliver workstations, monitors, laptops and selected peripherals/cables directly from in house Stores facilities.  This removes the need for City employees to wait an extended period of time for ordering, processing and shipping that would usually happen with product procurement.

A good example of this standardization is the latest workstation model, the Dell Optiplex 7040.  Many have wondered why the size of the computer is smaller now.  The Panel had the opportunity to avail the City of technological advancement and recommend a platform that allows for a number of key advantages.  The smaller computers are easier to deploy.  Due to smaller size and less weight more of them can be transported in the same vehicle.  They are smaller and easier to put on the desk leaving leg room underneath while simultaneously not taking up much space above.  As the City is concerned for green computing, the smaller workstations create less waste due to less packaging and less production materials.  As an added bonus all these advantages are achieved while performance of the workstation is actually improved over that of the previous larger computers.

CONTENT_NAME: Emergency Radio System Replacement Project – Radios Go Live On New System!
TEXT:
By Karl Larson and Mark Tanner, Co-Project Managers, PSSRP

On October 11th a limited number of public safety agencies on the east side of the county were transitioned to the new P-25 Digital Emergency Radio system. This initial transition was very successful; consequently, all other public safety/first-responder agencies within the county were transitioned to the new system just a week later. Approximately 3800 radios in total are now on the new system. About 2300 remain on the legacy analog system but will be transitioned over in the coming months.

As with any large “go-live” there have been some issues arise. Examples include:

* Ensuring radio users are using the correct new talk groups to participate on the digital system. (Note: The analog system remains fully functional so if the wrong channel is selected the radio transmissions are still 100% supported)

* The different tone and improved clarity of the voice transmissions cause some users to not recognize other users’ voices as they have in the past. This will fade as an issue as users become accustomed to the sound characteristics of the new system.

* Volume levels of voice transmissions are not consistent across the various user agencies. Again, this will quickly decline as radio and infrastructure settings are fine-tuned.

* Some in-building signal amplifiers are not yet digital-compatible and will require upgrading. BTS/Comms is upgrading these systems in City-owned facilities. Other non-City agencies are also addressing their upgrades.

Training bulletins, videos and demonstrations by Police and Fire representatives have been very effective in helping the large number of public safety responders understand the changes they will experience in the new digital environment.

Overall, the new system is performing at and above expectations in terms of coverage and quality of service. This map shows the vendor’s 97.5% guaranteed coverage within Multnomah County. Only 22 (red tiles) of 1064 tiles failed to meet the 97.5% threshold. Coverage in the majority of these red areas still meets operational requirements.

The map below shows the actual effective range of the new system, as determined by physical testing with a mobile and a portable radio. As compared to the previous map, one can see that the actual coverage is way beyond the Multnomah County boundaries. The gold colored pins represent finite trouble spots, but exist only on the fringes of the effective range of the system.

As the BTS Radio team begins to transition the City’s non-public safety radio users (i.e. PBOT, Water Bureau, Parks Bureau) over to the new system, issues will be addressed when discovered. Additionally, the school districts, universities/colleges, a large group at the Port of Portland and a number of smaller user entities will be brought on board in the next 90 days.

CONTENT_NAME: Interference Hunting:  An Exercise in Patience and Persistence
TEXT:
By John Rowe, Electronics Technician II, BTS Communications

October 19th, 09:40 AM

A gas leak explosion in NW Portland levels a 4 story building, severely damaging several others, and blowing out windows three blocks away. It was almost immediately called a four alarm incident.  Three firefighters, two police officers, and three civilians were injured. When a mayday call went out from one of the injured firefighters, I got chills. Because of dogged dedication to resolving a reception issue, the call was heard loud and clear. Several weeks prior, communication could have been very challenging.

One of the more frustrating and challenging duties electronic technicians have is to identify, locate and deactivate interfering signals on the city’s public safety radio system. During these hunts, easily 85% of the technician’s time is spent waiting for the problem to occur, as it's almost always intermittent. The remaining time is spent scrambling to identify a direction or location before it subsides. Interference can come from ANY type of wireless (and sometimes NOT wireless!) device, such as baby monitors, closed circuit TV systems, wireless LAN and WAN systems, cable TV, etc. Sometimes completely inactive components such as coax connectors, sections of conduit, or pieces of tower structure can even generate interfering signals. I’ve even seen interference generated by defective, but functional memory chips in a personal computer but only under certain circumstances of processor activity. The initial stages of an interference hunt are usually an exercise in patience and persistence.

Imagine having to locate one unique vehicle in the Portland metro area. You don’t know where it is, when it will be moving, or what it looks like. All you know is that it makes its existence known on the area roads from time to time. And when it does, it hinders other traffic for seconds or minutes at a time, then disappears. Go find it and when you do, take the keys from the driver!

What follows is a true account of one of our more challenging hunts…

Sometime during the last few weeks of August, 2016

A 911 dispatcher calls a patrol car in the downtown area over the radio, on the central talkgroup. All cars on central hear a loud burst of static, then the final portion of the dispatcher’s call. No one responds, as the unit number being called was covered up by the static burst. The dispatcher tries again, unaware that her transmission is not getting through. The next time, it does. The unit being called responds, but all the dispatcher hears is the same loud burst of static, covering up the entire response from the patrol car. The dispatcher sees an indication on her dispatch display that the patrol car’s radio did transmit, assumes the officer responded and proceeds with the dispatch call.

This scenario repeats itself over the next few hours with increasing regularity and severity. Finally, the supervisors on the dispatch floor decide it’s time to engage the radio shop to investigate the problem. The other radio technicians, the engineering department, and I see the email from the dispatch floor and begin to monitor our radios. It’s only a matter of minutes before we hear the problem. We recognize it by its characteristics as an interfering radio signal, intermittent and very short in duration, but there long enough to affect radio communications. The hunt for clues begins.

The plan is to catch the problem happening, and using directional receiving equipment, get coordinates on the point of origination from two or more locations. The point of intersection will help narrow the search to a much smaller area. Geometry at work.

September 8th, Thursday

I start my on-call rotation today. I'll be the one dealing with the interference when dispatch pages me during after- hours occurrences. I setup the PR100 (interference detection gear) in the Suburban and hit the road at the first recurrence of trouble. This goes on for a couple days, but the signal is too short. I can't confirm what direction it’s coming from, or even what it looks like on our detection equipment. Eventually I need to return to regular assignments and duties.

A day or so later, while working at the Prune Hill (SW Camas, WA) radio site, we hear it on the radio and immediately began looking for it. Jeremy, one of the other radio techs, notices a flickering indication on the PR100 while he has it connected to the site’s receiver system. After a few more occurrences, he confirms that the flicker is definitely the interfering signal. The indications are distributed across several frequencies, not just one. Usually this is the type of interference we see from in-building cellular telephone and two-way radio amplifiers, also known as BDA’s (Bi-Directional Amplifiers) or DAS’s (Distributed Antenna Systems). Great! Now we know what to look for. All we have to do is locate it.

September 10th, Saturday

 After a few days of mixing my regular duties with interference chasing, I have little success. Then, at 11PM, I get a page that the problem has returned, and has been constant for several minutes. I shoot out the door and head towards Prune Hill, where we first identified it. Arriving near the radio site, I pull off the road and start up the detection gear. As I sit listening patiently, I hear several instances on the radio. But not once do I see the indications on the detection gear. Hmmm…I need to relocate. It's obviously strong enough SOMEWHERE to interfere with radio traffic.

A little after 1:00 AM I decide to head into Portland. I drive to Mt. Scott (SE Portland), and then to Council Crest (SW Portland) because they both afford a panoramic radio’s-eye view of the whole metro area. The occurrences have lessened considerably by 2:00. With only a 1 or 2-second window of presence, it is nearly impossible to capture on the detection gear, let alone get a direction to its source. Sitting…waiting…listening…sipping Mountain Dew, the on-call tech’s best friend! Well, mine anyway. 4:00 approaches, and I’ve heard no instances for over an hour. So I call it a night and go home.

September 12th, Monday

As the reports increase and the problem seems more intrusive, the decision is made for me to devote my entire shift to resolving the issue. I'm somewhat relieved, and at the same time a bit apprehensive. I know that the extra time hunting will help to identify and locate it, but at the same time the expectation for a resolution will also increase.

My days now consist of turning on the radio and PR100 detection equipment as soon as I get into the Suburban in the morning and heading into the downtown area. Prune Hill has been unproductive for locking onto the signal. Alarms generated by the radio system seem to indicate it is coming from the downtown area.

September 14th, Wednesday

Two more days have gone by with little progress. The occurrences have been much shorter than usual lately, maybe only affecting one or two radio transmissions, then nothing for two or more hours. It seems the harder I search, the more elusive the interference gets. It's very frustrating. I thought I would have found it by now. Several days have been devoted to hunting it.

We contacted our neighboring public safety agencies to see if they have been having the same issues. Washington County reports they too have been getting hit by it. So, it's affecting both sides of the West Hills. I decide to set up at our Council Crest radio site for the day. It affords a good view to both downtown Portland, and into Beaverton. It has also been the site most consistent in logging interference alarms on the radio system.

It’s a beautiful day, so I set up in a shady spot in the park. Fifteen minutes into my vigil I'm rewarded with a particularly long episode of interference, some 10-15 minutes in duration. I quickly tune the PR100 to the frequencies we were checking at Prune Hill and immediately see the flickering, barely-there indications. As I swing the directional antenna full circle, I manage to lock the seemingly strongest indication coming from a north-northeasterly direction. Maybe the NW industrial area, but nothing from the Washington county area. Now, if I can just get another heading locked in from another location. The PR100 has the wonderful ability to triangulate two such directions (vectors) and display the approximate location on a GPS-synced map.

I spend the rest of my day parked on Willamette Boulevard in North Portland, giving me a good clear view over the NW and Swan Island industrial areas. I can get a good second vector from here but the interference has subsided for the day.

Finally, after over two weeks, some noteworthy progress!! I am encouraged. This may be a winnable battle yet.

September 16th, Friday

Two days of hunting from Willamette Boulevard have been unproductive. The familiar indications are so weak, if even visible on the PR100, that getting a solid direction isn't possible. The momentary bursts that occur every couple hours are not helping the effort. I don’t understand. When at Council Crest, the equipment indicated it was coming from this direction. Yet I can barely see it here. The one or two best indications I get are in a direction that doesn’t even intersect with the vector I saw at Council Crest. Now the signals seem to be coming from downtown, maybe east of the Willamette River.

I spend the remainder of the day on a hilltop near Powell and McLoughlin, sitting, waiting. But again, the bursts are too short to be useful. It seems to be coming from somewhere to the North. I end my shift frustrated, again wondering if I will ever find the source.

September 17th, Saturday

My pager lights up around 8 PM. Here we go again. Until 3 AM the next morning, I drive to various locations. I try desperately to get a direction on the interference from ANYWHERE around or East of the downtown area. Once again, the bursts are too short.

As I’m driving about, I take some comfort in the fact that the early morning hours are great for interference hunting. I have the roads and highways all to myself. No traffic to deal with, no one behind me honking as I roll slowly down the street with an antenna out the window. I can pull a U-turn wherever I want, just turn on the vehicle strobes and proceed. I can and did, drive down I-84 Westbound at about 25 MPH at one time. Once, when I picked up a fairly strong indication on the detection gear, I was able to safely shoot across all three freeway lanes to take an exit that was imminent.

I noticed while moving down I-5 South to I-84 East that the ramp to I-84 would be a good place to sit on my next outing. There is ample room to pull over out of daytime traffic and get a good path and view of the central downtown area, both sides of the river. I decide to give it a try, desperate to make some sort of progress. My “perch” on the I-84 Eastbound ramp has provided the strongest indications yet. Unfortunately, the signal seems to be coming from all directions. I must be close, close enough that I don’t have any directivity on the interference.

September 26, Monday – A breakthrough

The reports of interference have tapered off, possibly due to the radio system users just dealing with the bursts when they occur, and possibly cooler weather moving in. High temperatures often aggravate these issues.

 Sitting and waiting for the occurrences has proven futile. The duration is just too short to confirm a direction. I’ve decided to drive to the locations (very few) in the area where I know there is a BDA installation, and hopefully just be in the right neighborhood when the interference occurs. I am running out of time and patience.

Ed Connolly, one of our system engineers, has suggested an apartment complex in the area that he knows has a BDA system. It's about 10 blocks straight east of the I-84 ramp. I get no results from that location. The PR100 is still showing indications but much weaker and still pointing back to the I-84 ramp area. The occurrences subside for the day. So I head home, more frustrated than ever.

Around 5 PM, just after I get home, the pager goes off. Dejected and hungry, I head back into town. My destination will be the I-84 ramp. As I am listening to the radio on my way there, the interference is making its presence known in a big way. I cringe every time I hear it, feeling the mounting pressure to find and eliminate it.

I sit on the side of the ramp for about half an hour, waving the directional antenna about wildly during each burst, trying to get a direction. I try different directional antennas, and different detection gear. Except for the variances in test equipment, the results are always the same, strong indications in all directions.

To be seemingly so close, yet still no idea where it’s coming from pushes my frustration up further. I pull the antenna back into the vehicle to give my arm a rest. I consider throwing in the towel and suggesting another tech take over. Sometimes a fresh set of eyes and perspective are all it takes. I glare hatefully at the PR100 and its dancing, flickering indications. Things are getting personal now. I think to myself, “This interference is trying to get me fired!” I lean back, take a breath, remind myself that all my data thus far must have a logical explanation, and focus my attention on the PR100 again.

Using some of the analytical abilities of the PR100, I manage to isolate the strongest indications to a frequency very near to the radio system’s control channel. This channel is used by the central controller, the brains and “traffic cop” of the radio system. Everything a radio does is communicated to the central controller via the control channel: keying up, roaming to a different coverage area, even changing channels (or “talkgroups”, as they are called in this type of radio system).

I narrow the PR100’s receiver down to just the control channel, and watch for indications I can glean more clues from. I watch the various data bursts from the radios scattered about the area on the screen, along with the occasional interference burst. Before long, I notice something. The interference is NEVER present prior to a radio transmission; only immediately after a data burst from a radio. Not all of them, only the data bursts from what seems to be nearby radios. This again indicates something is going on in the area near my location. I wonder if the interference is actually being triggered by the local data bursts from nearby radios. I change the talkgroup on the mobile radio in the Suburban and watch the PR100. Right on cue, immediately after my radio’s data burst is transmitted, there was the interference indication! I try again several times to verify my theory with the same results. I can actually force the problem to happen!  What a huge breakthrough. This is the best finding I've made since I started hunting.

I call the 911 dispatch supervisor to let them know I am going to trigger the interference for the next several minutes. I'm close to locating it and this will help immensely. After about 45 minutes of channel changing and driving in four different directions in that area, I find myself at the intersection of SE 10th and Ankeny. The indications here are almost off the scale when pointed at an apartment building on the northeast corner, "The Lofts at Lower Burnside". The office is dark. I'll be back first thing tomorrow morning.

The next day I head right over and conduct a floor by floor walkthrough using the detection gear. Indications are strongest on the 6th (top) floor. The leasing agent gives me access to the only communications room she’s aware of, but it's a dead end. Closer, but still no luck. She informs me that maintenance and management crews will both be there the next day. I promised to return the next morning.

September 28, 2016 – Success!

I meet the maintenance person and toured the building. Our first destination - the roof. The presence of any kind of antennas provide additional clues. Emerging through the access hatch, the first thing I notice is a “yagi” antenna, a highly directional, energy-multiplying type of antenna pointed directly at the Council Crest radio site. Aiming the PR100’s directional antenna, I change channels on my portable radio and see a flood of radiated interference come from the building antenna. I’ve got you now, my pretty, I think to myself.

I ask where the antenna cable runs to. “Probably one of the comm closets” he responds. We go to the 4th floor where I am shown a utility closet I hadn't visited. Anticipation builds. I'm eager to see what’s on the other side of the door. My search may soon be over.

As we step into the room, we are greeted by a wave of +90° heat, surprising given that it’s only in the 70’s outside. We scan the room for the corrugated coax antenna cable. We find it dropping through the ceiling and disappearing into an enclosed cabinet that has been jammed into the tight sauna-like room. Opening the cabinet, we find several backup power supply units at the bottom of the rack, their fans straining to move the excessive heat. Halfway up is a beige metal enclosure connected to a small networking device and to the corrugated coax. It’s noticeably hot to the touch and bears a label identifying it as a type of radio signal booster. It was obvious that this was the device causing the problem. After a few minutes’ discussion with the maintenance man, we decide it's not critical building communications equipment. I turn its power switch off and step back into the hallway. As I switch channels on my radio, I am delighted to see on my test gear a clean spectrum after each data burst from my portable radio. Finally, after over a month of persistent, incremental progress, I’ve found it. If I didn’t have to maintain a professional composure, I’d break into a happy dance!

Upon reflection, all the odd and conflicting data I had collected now made sense. Once I had collected enough information about signal strength and direction, I was in the neighborhood. All I needed was that extra bit of control to zero in on it. This was certainly one of the toughest ones to track down, and an excellent learning experience.

CONTENT_NAME: Police IT Finds Success In Deployment of Secure Smart Phones
TEXT:
By Chad Lublin and Cloy Swartzendruber

Over the course of the past year, the Police Bureau and the BTS Police IT support group have been working together along with the BTS Communications Division and Verizon Wireless to prepare for a deployment of Apple iPhones throughout the Police Bureau.

The large scale deployment of 983 Apple iPhone 6's began on August 8th and was completed on September 6th.  We also deployed 52 Android phones.  All 1035 phones are managed and controlled under the Mobile Data Management system, Airwatch.  We are also using Mobile VPN through NetMotion.  This deployment of 1035 phones ran 3 days a week, Tuesday through Thursday for five weeks.  This was the culmination of a yearlong effort.

Highlights of the project include:

  • Implementation of unprecedented secure mobile technology, Airwatch,
  • Development of a deployment process that necessitated less than a quarter of the time normally required by professional consumer vendors,
  • Development and implementation of a tool used by callout units to securely share information,
  • Development of a comprehensive sustainment and support plan that included multiple city and non-city groups,
  • Development of a process to conduct functional, security, and fiscal reviews of mobile application requests,
  • Approving and implementing 43 of 56 application requests,
  • Training of all Police Bureau members, including preparing administrators for front line support,
  • Overcoming technical issues that originated from non-city entities that would have otherwise been detrimental to the success of the project, and
  • Assisting Gresham Police Department in developing a similar project.

The mobile technology deployed has already proven invaluable to sworn on the street, allowing them to perform nearly all technical-related duties typically performed inside a precinct or in a patrol car.  On the first day Police Central Precinct received their phones, a report of a subject who walked away from an inmate work crew was broadcast.  Using their newly issued smart phones, officers received a picture of the subject and were easily able to review the picture on their phones. Officers were then able to show the picture to members of the community who positively identified the subject. This resulted in information that the subject had left a park and entered a hospital.  Sergeants on the street were able to get the video pictures of the subject from the hospital and send these pictures to all officers within hours of the subject walking away.  The subject was later obtained and arrested in Lane County.

 

A lunch time celebration held for the team and was attended by Police Chief Marshman, Assistant Chief Wagenknecht, our Chief Technology Officer, Jeff Baer and our Deputy CTO, Dan Bauer.

This is an example of the good work that is possible when technical and law enforcement personnel work together.

Thanks to all those involved. From BTS this included:

CONTENT_NAME: What's Going On With the Data Center Move?
TEXT:
By Valerie Perkinson

The Data Center Move Project comprises the moving of all infrastructure hardware, except telecom, out of the Portland Building Data Center prior to the beginning of TPB construction. The Portland Data Center will be moved to a Co-location facility, which has yet to be chosen.  The Data Center will not be brought back to TPB after renovation, but will remain at the Co-location facility.

Why are we moving the Data Center?

The TPB renovation project is driving the completion date, as we want all of the servers out of the building prior to the start of construction.  However, this is not the primary factor driving the move.  The move to a co-location facility will also provide increased reliability for the City’s critical applications.  This is achieved by providing for:

  • Power redundancies
  • Cooling redundancies
  • Cable Management
  • 24/7 staffing
  • Increased security
  • A platform for Disaster Recovery

What is a Co-Location (COLO) Center?

Co-location (COLO) facilities have become a prevalent method in which many private sector and government entities manage their data centers.  COLO facilities are a type of data center where equipment, space and bandwidth are available to rent. 

From the outside, COLO centers look like typical corporate buildings.  However, the interiors of the buildings are quite impressive.  They contain secure suites and/or cages for client data centers, two sets of backup generators, two sets of air conditioners, fire protection, and cable management.  COLO facilities also provide “remote hands” (someone available 24/7 to mount or power on/off a server).  Many COLO facilities also offer server management services.

COLO facilities are known for their incredible security.  The exterior of the buildings are gated with a 24/7 security guard on duty.  All vehicles are stopped at the gate.  Upon entering the building, photo IDs must be shown and clients are escorted to their server areas.

COLO facilities provide a superior environment for a data center.  With 24/7 monitoring and redundant cooling and power, most business entities cannot staff or finance this type of data center.  The City’s data center and its critical applications will realize less down-time at a significantly lower cost.

Choosing the City’s Co-Location Facility

The City engaged a neutral, third-party, computer center firm (who will not be bidding) to analyze the existing 3rd floor data center at TPB and provide recommendations on what should be included in the RFP.  This study was completed in May 2016.  The City released the RFP on September 7, 2016 and it will close on September 30, 2016.  It will take 3 to 4 weeks to review the RFP responses, conduct site visits, score the RFPs and award the bid.  The selection process should be completed by the end of October 2016.

Migration Strategy

Once the WAN (Wide Area Network) is extended to the new COLO facility, the existing data center on the 3rd floor of TPB and the COLO data center will operate as one data center.  Data can then be replicated across the network.  The City’s servers are approximately 84% virtualized, however, there are some physical servers that will need to be moved.  Once all the testing is complete, a phased cut-over will take place.

Schedule

The below schedule will change as we solidify the dates for the COLO selection, WAN availability and TPB renovation dates.  The dates displayed below are estimates.

 

Bureau’s Participation

The Data Center Move project needs the Bureau’s participation in the following 4 areas:


1. Application Inventory


• All Server based applications are currently being inventoried. Vertical Application Team members, TBCs and BTS representatives are in the process of contacting each Bureau to find out Application and dependency information.
• When will this take place? Between now and November 2016.


2. Current Performance Measurements


• Measurements on how critical applications are performing now are being taken.
• This information will be used for:


o Before the move


» User Acceptance Testing


» Troubleshooting, if necessary


o After the move


» COLO Facility Support


• When will this take place? Between now and November 2016.


 
3. User Acceptance Testing


• The Bureau’s will test their critical applications on a Lab PC that is pointing to the COLO Facility.
• The tester will sign-off on their application indicating that the application is running correctly.
• The cut-over to the COLO Facility will take place after user acceptance testing is complete.
• When will this take place? June 2017 through November 2017.


4. Move Schedule


• The Bureaus will participate in move schedule meetings to ensure that their application move dates do not interfere with other Bureau activities.
• The timeframe for the application moves may change as TPB Renovation Project establishes their dates for building demolition.
• When will this take place? May 2017 through July 2017.

What is taking place now?

An enormous amount of planning is required for a Data Center Move.  The Network Team is designing the new WAN as well as designing the network at the new COLO Facility.  The Storage and Server Teams are architecting the new COLO environment.  There have been many meetings with vendors, and all teams are discussing how everything will work together at the COLO center.

Data Center Move Project has its Own Page on the BTS section of PortlandOregon.gov

The Data Center Move page is on the BTS section of PortlandOregon.gov and is available to all City employees.  It is a non-technical page which contains the project’s dashboards and current status, information about the project, and PowerPoint presentations from all past Data Center Move meetings.

It can be accessed via:

  • https://www.portlandoregon.gov/bts/DataCenterMove

or

  • Going to the BTS page and clicking on “Project News & Information”

CONTENT_NAME: Working to Improve Trust in Our Working Relationships
TEXT:
By Dan Bauer, BTS Deputy Director

At our last BTS all-staff meeting the Labor Management Committee (LMC) presented the BTS Trust Survey results and led an open conversation to ideas to improve bureau trust in our working relationships.  Out of that idea generation several key themes emerged and I am writing to provide an update on work done by the LMC and others on those items.  The top four items from the idea generation and a status of actions to date are included below.

  • Pilot a training and professional development program
    • Status: The BTS LMC has partnered with Franklin Covey to host courses for staff using the program based on the book “ The Speed of Trust”  Under this partnership we have had over 90 BTS team members attend the course.  There has been an overwhelming positive feedback regarding the course and its relevance to our professional and personal lives.  A testament to the high level of interest is that our 3rd class of 50 seats schedule for July 20th was completely filled in approximately 8 hours after the email was sent out to solicit attendance.  Other updates on this item include:
      • Regular discussions (called Trust Huddles) are taking place in many team meetings across BTS.  These discussions delve deeper into the course materials and can help transition from classroom learning to cultural change.
      • Several LMC members have stepped forward to become certified to teach the “Speed of Trust” course such that we can continue to provide this valuable experience to new staff as part of our onboarding practices.
      • A fourth Speed of Trust course will be held in September after the summer vacation season.

 

  • Professional Development resources
    • Status:  The BTS LMC has engaged Franklin Covey to provide professional development resources.  This is via the newly released All Access Pass which provides learning content on the 23 curriculum areas.  This will be rolled in the coming weeks.  A short video of the All Access Pass is available here: http://www.franklincovey.de/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/AAP-Say-Hello.htm.  Additionally BTS is committed to providing access to the ACM http://www.acm.org/ membership and learning resources.  Via ACM’s digital library staff have access to thousands  of technical books, webinars and pre-certification curriculum to further professional development.  The LMC is also supportive of the COPPEA Professional Development fund as an additional avenue for professional development resources for COPPEA staff.

 

  • Explore opportunities for employee recognition
    • Status:  The  BTS LMC has formed a subcommittee to look at ways to enhance employee recognition.  Additionally to encourage recognition BTS Thank You cards are available at The Portland building, the 1900 building and the Communications Center.  These cards are an easy and meaningful way to provide a hand written thank you to coworkers or customers.  Over the last few months several hundred of these have already been used to recognize and thank our coworkers.

 

  • Quarterly CTO/DCTO meetings with staff at the 1900 building and Communications Center
    • Status:  Jeff and Dan have begun periodic meetings with teams at locations other than the Portland building.  These will continue as both Jeff and Dan are committed to providing opportunities to meet directly with teams to listen, share information, and create transparency with all staff.

 

As the LMC continues to fulfill its mission to improve employee satisfaction, productivity and efficiency by promoting trust, fairness and open communication between Labor and Management we are always welcome to receive feedback and ideas from our dedicated and talented employees.  We encourage you to visit the LMC website to learn more about our activities: http://www.portlandoregon.gov/bts/lmc

CONTENT_NAME: One Year Later on Trust -- Where Are We?
TEXT:
By Brian Ventura, Information Security

The Speed of Trust (SoT) adventure started more than a year ago, but most of BTS had their first introduction with the Trust Survey in May/June 2015. Prior to that date, the BTS LMC started talking about new issues to tackle around September 2014. At that time, we discussed complaints and concerns to find out if there was a core issue we could address across BTS. Many of these issues had a common thread or root cause, which we started to identify as Trust, or lack of trust. We identified FranklinCovey’s Speed of Trust program and LMC members went to a ½ day SoT seminar. From this review, we agreed their program is a good way to address issues within BTS. One key takeaway from the seminar was: this is an ongoing process, not a train once and we are fixed. The LMC committed to following through with the process.

The first engagement was the survey in May 2015. The survey gave us an eye-opening or distinct view of the trust levels in BTS. We decided an external survey would give us an objective view. We saw there were significant trust taxes within BTS. We presented these results to BTS at the All Hands meeting that Fall. We also asked for feedback at the All Hands meeting and received a great list of recommendations! I will talk about those in a bit. 

In February this year, Management and the LMC labor members attended the 2-day, Leading at the Speed of Trust, training. This was a great event, with some excellent conversation. This group identified the highest impact SoT card, affecting BTS. We identified “Create Transparency” as a weakness and Management agreed to focus on Creating Transparency in BTS.

Part of the Speed of Trust program is to participate or lead trust huddles in team meetings. Management took on this task and led their teams through the weekly trust huddle program. How far along is your team? The goal of these trust huddles is to keep the conversation open and identify areas we can make a difference in our work: apply the program to real issues in your team or between your team and another.

In May, the first Speed of Trust Foundation training was held for staff. This group got a special treat at the World Trade Center, since all the meeting rooms at the Portland Building were booked. The World Trade Center had some excellent food. This session had approximately forty BTS staff members and introduced the material. It went through similar exercises as the Leadership training, allowing staff to get a great view of the Speed of Trust program. Again, we had great participation and ideas flow from the event.

July brought us our second Foundation training, at the Communications Center. Fifty BTS staff members participated in the training and came away with excellent insight on how to impact the BTS culture and make this a great place to work. During this training, we introduced the FranklinCovey All-Access pass! This allows BTS employees to have on demand access to over fifty courses provided by FranklinCovey, including Speed of Trust. This included Impact Journeys to enhance our knowledge and practice in the Speed of Trust. Don’t know about All-Access, but you went to training? We have you covered. We have upcoming brown-bag lunches to introduce the All-Access and provide Impact Journeys! Keep your eyes open for the announcement. This group received royal treatment with burgers and hot dogs grilled onsite by Jeff and Dan!! They also had a waffle breakfast catered by a local favorite food cart! Great food again. We will have to see what culinary treats the final training provides.

We have one more Foundation training coming up in September. If you have not attended yet, this is your opportunity. We anticipate getting the remaining staff through this training. After that, we can take this to the next level! This training will be in the 1900 building. Watch for the invite! Further, a number of LMC members volunteered to become Speed of Trust Facilitators, to provide ongoing training opportunities for new staff over the years.

What about those recommendations from the All Hands meeting? What did the LMC do with those? Well, we started working on those, in-between and in conjunction with the Speed of Trust program. Dan has a write-up on the status and here is a summary:

  • Professional Development - BTS engaged with FranklinCovey on their full line of on demand courses, pushed the use of ACM.
  • Recognition - The LMC tasked the Recognition Committee to discuss options with workgroups and provide recommendations.
  • Transparency - A commitment from Jeff and Dan to have quarterly CTO/DCTO meetings
  • These are just a few things. More to come.

We are BTS. Your help is needed. Take on the Speed of Trust; look to your four cores. Is there someone you need to restore trust with? Is there someone to whom you could extend Smart Trust? In what behaviors are you strong? Weak? How can you work on strengthening these?

CONTENT_NAME: Public Safety Radio Upgrade Project
TEXT:
By Mark Tanner, Public Safety Systems Revitalization Program Radio Project Manager                                                          

Over the past several years there has been a large, complex communications project making significant progress within the City.  The Public Safety Systems Revitalization Program (PSSRP) team, in close collaboration with the BTS Communications (Radio) group, has been engaged in replacing the mission-critical Emergency Radio System that services all of the public safety agencies that operate within the Multnomah County borders.  The City of Portland's non-public safety bureaus also rely on this system for radio service.

At a cost of over $50M, the legacy analog radio system is being replaced with state-of-the-art Motorola digital P-25 compliant technology.   “P-25”??  The long name is “APCO Project 25” and is explained in the graph below.  It’s basically a way to make sure public safety agencies in a given region can all communicate.

There are well over 6000 radios of various types registered on the system.  As shown here, the majority are those used by City bureaus, especially Police and Fire.  However, there are actually over 60 agencies that utilize this system, including school districts, universities, federal agencies, private companies and other municipalities.

The system provides radio coverage to the service area through a network of 14 radio towers.  The towers are located in various upper elevation locations in and around the county.  Each tower site has back-up power and equipment redundancy in order to support the mission-critical requirements of the system.  It’s interesting to note that it is estimated that approximately 85 towers would be required to cover this same area for cellular phone service. 

The radio systems of Clark County, Washington, Clackamas County, and Washington County are also being upgraded to P25 Digital standards.  Once all systems are complete, the coverage footprint for these systems will extend from as far north as Cowlitz County, Washington to as far south as Salem, Oregon, and provide interoperability and mutual aid communications.

The new hand-held and vehicle radios being provided to the City's radio users match the new infrastructure when it comes to features and reliability.  For example, the hand-held radio that Portland Fire now uses offers the following features and characteristics:

Physical Characteristics

  •  Display: Top and front
  •  Keypad: Full or None
  •  Emergency button: Programmable
  •  Weight (with standard battery): 16.4 oz
  •  Dimensions H x W x D (with standard battery): 5.47 x 2.98 x 1.6 inches
  •  Large knobs to accommodate gloved-hand control

Radio Features

  •  Advanced Software Features: Over the Air Programming (OTAP)
  •  Noise reduction software: Yes
  •  Number of channels: Max channel capacity 1250
  •  Audio Profiles: Yes
  •  Voice operated transmit (VOX): Yes
  •  Integrated voice and data: Yes
  •  Text messaging capable: Yes
  •  GPS operation: Yes
  •  Bluetooth connectivity: Yes
  •  CPS (Customer Programming Software): Yes
  •  Signaling: ASTRO® and ASTRO 25
  •  Status calls: Yes
  •  Time out timer: Yes
  •  Programmable buttons: Yes

User Environment

  •  Intrinsically safe: Yes (spark free for use in hazmat environments)
  •  Water resistance: Up to 30 min. in up to 40” of water
  •  Submersible: Yes
  •  Man-down feature: Yes
  •  Emergency button on remote speaker mic: Yes
  •  Speaker mic includes background noise cancellation: Yes

What’s next?

The system is set to be in full use by the 4th quarter of 2016.  All radio users will have the advantage of all that “P25” offers in this system, with additional capacity and enhanced abilities to communicate.

While the Radio Project installation phase winds down in 2016, there are additional enhancements that will be brought on line in 2017.  A digital connection known as WAVE will be activated and will allow certain users to access the radio system through their own cell phones, giving a much broader footprint and coverage for radio system users.  While not “mission critical” voice, it will allow non-critical, routine radio traffic to be transmitted and received anywhere cell coverage is available and will work across the United States and Canada.

CONTENT_NAME: BTS Recognition Committee Formed
TEXT:
By Matt Freid, Corporate GIS Manager

The BTS Recognition Committee is a new group formed by the LMC to create new opportunities for everyone in the bureau to show their appreciation for the great things we do for our customers and each other.    We want to provide you with a variety of ways to recognize individuals and groups as well as have the spotlight shown on what you do. 

What We Are Doing

We have gotten a group of BTS staff together to brainstorm ideas, and then have gone out to staff meetings at different workgroups and work sites to see what people thought about them.  We want to find ways to recognize your work in a way that fits your personality, so we talked a lot about not just things that people liked but also ones they don’t like.   Based on that feedback we are starting with a first effort: an award that is passed from one employee to another to in appreciation of their help or customer service.    Think of it like an IT themed Stanley Cup – you get to display it  or even show it off during a ticker tape parade and then it goes to the next deserving individual after a month.    Look for more efforts to follow based on your feedback.   

Who We Are

Matthew Freid, Corporate GIS

Emily Tabachnick, Police IT

Bryan Pirello, Support Center

Charlie Ferranti, Help Desk  

Paul Cone, Corporate GIS

We'd also love to have more participants, so if you are interested in joining the committee please contact Matt Freid for more information.
